editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: CURE FOR A CUCKOLD. A PLEASANT COMEDY, As it hath been ſeveral times Acted with great Applauſe.
Written by JOHN VVEBSTER and VVILLIAM ROWLEY.

London, Printed by Tho. Johnſon, and are to be ſold by Francis Kirkman, at his Shop at the Sign of John Fletchers Head, over againſt the Angel Inne, on the Back-ſide of St. Clements, without Temple-Bar. 1661.

div.head: The Stationer, to the Judicious Reader.
div.p: IT was not long 〈◊〉 I was onely a Book-Reader, and not a Book-ſeller, which Quality (my former Employment ſomewhat failing, and I being unwilling to be idle) I have now lately taken on me. It hath been my fancy and delight (ere ſince I knew any thing) to converſe with Books; and the pleaſure I have taken in thoſe of this nature, (viz. Plays) hath bin ſo extraordinary, that it hath bin much to my coſt; 〈◊〉 I have been (as we term it) a Gatherer of Plays for ſome years, and I am confident I have more of ſeveral ſorts than any man in England, Book-ſeller, or other: I can at any time ſhew 700 in number, which is within a ſmall matter all that were ever printed. Many of theſe I have ſeveral times over, and intend as I ſell, to purchaſe more; All, or any of which, I ſhall be ready either to ſell or lend to you upon reaſonable Conſiderations.

In order to the increaſing of my Store, I have now this Tearm printed and publiſhed three, viz. This called A Cure for a Cuckold, and another called, The Thracian Wonder; and the third called, Gammer Gurtons Needle. Two of theſe three were never printed, the third, viz. Gammer Gurtons Needle, hath bin formerly printed, but it is almoſt an hundred years ſince. As for this Play, I need not ſpeak any thing in its Commendation, the Authors names, Webſter and Rowley, are (to knowing men) ſufficient to declare its worth: ſeveral perſons remember the Acting of it, and ſay that it then pleaſed generally well; and let me tell you, in my judgement it is an excellent old Play. The Expedient of Curing a Cuckold (after the maner ſet down in this Play) hath bin tried to my knowledge, and therefore I may ſay Probatum eſt. I ſhould, I doubt, be too tedious, or elſe I would ſay ſomewhat in defence of this, and in Commendation of 〈◊〉 in general, but I queſtion not but you have read what abler Pens than mine have writ in their Vindication. Gentlemen, I hope you will ſo incourage me in my beginnings, that I may be induced to proceed to do you ſervice, and that I may frequently have occaſion in this nature, to ſubſcribe my ſelf

list.head: Dramatis Perſonae.
list.item: VVOodroff, a Juſtice of the Peace, Father to Annabel.
Franckford a Merchant, Brother in Law to Woodroff.
Leſsingham a Gentleman in love with Clare.
Bonvile a Gentleman, the Bridegroom and Husband to Annabel.
Grover, Gallants invited to the Wedding.
Rochfield, a young Gentleman, and a Thief.
Luce Wife to Franckford, and Siſter to Woodroff.
Annabel the Bride, and Wife to Bonvile.

sp.speaker: Leſſ.
sp.p: THis is a place of feaſting and of joy, and as in Triumphs and Ovations here, nothing ſave ſtate and pleaſure.

sp.speaker: Clare.
sp.p: 'Tis confeſt.

sp.speaker: Leſſ.
sp.p: A day of Mirth and ſolemn Jubile.

sp.speaker: Clare.
sp.p: For ſuch as can be merry.

sp.speaker: Leſſ.
sp.p: A happy Nuptial, ſince a like pair of Fortunes ſuitable, equality in Birth, parity in years, and in affection no way different are this day ſweetly coupled.

sp.speaker: Clare.
sp.p: 'Tis a Marriage.

sp.speaker: Leſſ.
sp.p: True Lady, and a noble preſident me thinks for us to follow: why ſhould theſe out-ſtrip us in our loves, that have not yet out-gone us in our time.
If we thus looſe our beſt, and not to be recovered hours unprofitably ſpent, we ſhall be held meer Trewants in Loves ſchool.

sp.speaker: Clare.
sp.p: That's a ſtudy in which I never-ſhall ambition have to become graduate.

sp.speaker: Leſſ.
sp.p: Lady, you are ſad: this Jovial Meeting puts me in a ſpirit to be made ſuch.
We two are Gueſts invited, and meet by purpoſe, not by accident; where's then a place more opportunely fit, in which we may ſolicite our own Loves, than before this example?

sp.speaker: Clare.
sp.p: In a word, I purpoſe not to marry.

sp.speaker: Leſſ.
sp.p: By your favor, for as I ever to this preſent hour have ſtudied your obſervance, ſo from henceforth I now will ſtudy plainneſs, I hav • loved you beyond my ſelf, mis-ſpended for your ſake many a fair hour, which might have been imployed to pleaſure, or to profit, have neglected duty to them from whom my being came, my parents; but my hopeful ſtudies moſt.

I have ſtol'n time from all my choice delights, and robb'd my
ſelf, 〈…〉 have told me as fair, as rich, I never thought 'em ſo, and loſt all theſe in hope to finde out you, reſolve me then for Chriſtian charity. Think you an Anſwer of that • rozen nature is a ſufficient ſatisfaction for ſo many more then needful ſervices?

sp.speaker: Clare.
sp.p: I have ſaid, Sir.

sp.speaker: Leſſ.
sp.p: Whence might this diſtaſte ariſe? Be at leaſt ſo kinde to perfect me in that: Is it of ſome diſlike lately conceived of this my perſon, which perhaps may grow from calumny and ſcandal? if not that, ſome late received Melancholy in you: if neither, your perverſe and peeviſh will, to which I moſt i •• ly it.

sp.speaker: Clare.
sp.l: Be it what it can, or may be, thus it is,
And with this Anſwer pray reſt ſatisfied.
In all theſe travels, windings, and indents,
Paths, and by-paths which many have ſought out,
There's but one onely road, and that alone
To my fruition; which who ſo findes out,
'Tis like he may enjoy me: but that failing,
I ever am mine own.

sp.speaker: Leſſ.
sp.p: Oh name it, Sweet. I am already in a Labyrinth until you guide me out.

sp.speaker: Clare.
sp.l: Ile to my Chamber,
May you be pleaſed, unto your mis-ſpent time
To adde but ſome few minutes. By my Maid
You ſhall hear further from me.

sp.speaker: Leſſ.
sp.l: Ile attend you.
What more can I deſire, than be reſolv'd
Of ſuch a long ſuſpence. Here's now the period
Of much expectation.
sp.stage: Enter Raymond, Euſtace, Lyonel, and Grover, Gallants.

sp.speaker: Raym.
sp.l: What? you alone
Retired to privacy,
Of ſuch a goodly confluence, all prepared
To grace the preſent Nuptials?

sp.speaker: Leſſ.
sp.p: I have heard ſome ſay, men are ne're leſs alone, then when alone, ſuch power hath meditation.

sp.speaker: Euſt.
sp.p: Oh theſe choice Beauties that are this day aſſembled! But of all, fair Miſtriſs Clare, the Bride excepted ſtill, ſhe bears away the prize.

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.p: And worthily; for, ſetting off her preſent melancholly, ſhe is without taxation.

sp.speaker: Grov.
sp.p: I conceive the cauſe of her ſo ſudden diſcontent.

sp.speaker: Raym.
sp.p: 'Tis far out of my way.

sp.speaker: Grov.
sp.p: Ile ſpeak it then: In all eſtates, profeſſions, or degrees in Arts or Sciences, there is a kinde of Emulation; likewiſe ſo in this: There's a Maid this day married, a choice Beauty. Now Mrs. Clare, a Virgin of like Age, and Fortunes correſpondent, apprehending time loſt in her that's in another gained, may upon this. For who knows womens thoughts grow into this deep ſadneſs?

sp.speaker: Raym.
sp.p: Like enough.

sp.speaker: Leſſ.
sp.l: You are pleaſant, Gentlemen,
Or elſe perhaps, though I know many have purſued her Love,

sp.speaker: Grov.
sp.l: (And you amongſt the reſt) with pardon Sir,
Yet ſhe might caſt ſome more peculiar eye
On ſome that not reſpects her,

sp.speaker: Leſſ.
sp.p: That's my fear which you now make your ſport.

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.p: A Letter, Sir.

sp.speaker: Leſſ.
sp.p: From whom?

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.p: My Miſtriſs.

sp.speaker: Leſſ.
sp.p: She has kept her promiſe, and I will read it, though I in the ſame know my own death included.

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.p: Fare you well, Sir.

l.hi: Prove all thy friends, finde out the beſt and neareſt,
Kill for my ſake that Friend that loves thee deareſt.

lg.l: Her ſervant, nay her hand and character,
All meeting in my ruine! Read agen,

l.hi: Prove all thy Friends, finde out the beſt and neareſt,
Kill for my ſake that Friend that loves the deareſt.

lg.l: And what might that one be? 'Tis a ſtrange difficulty,
And it will ask much councel.

sp.speaker: Raym.
sp.p: Leſſingham hath left us on the ſudden.

sp.speaker: Euſt.
sp.p: Sure the occaſion was of that Letter ſent him.

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.p: 〈…〉 be it was ſome Challenge.

sp.speaker: Grov.
sp.l: Challenge, never dream it:
Are ſuch things ſent by women?
sp.stage: Enter Woodroff, A • abel, B •• vile, Franckfor • , Luce, and Nurſe.

sp.speaker: Raym.
sp.l: 'Twere an Hereſie
To conceive but ſuch a thought.

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.l: Tuſh, all the difference
Begot this day, muſt be at night decided
Betwixt the Bride and Bridegroom. Here both come.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: What did you call the Gentleman we met But now in ſome diſtraction?

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: Leſſingham: A moſt approv'd and noble friend of mine, and one of our prime Gueſts.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.l: He ſeemed to me
Somewhat in minde diſtemper'd. What concern
Thoſe private humors ours ſo publick Mirth
In ſuch a time of Revels? Miſtriſs Clare,
I miſs her too. Why Gallants, have you ſuffered her
Thus to be loſt amongſt you?

sp.speaker: Anna.
sp.p: Dinner done, unknown to any, ſhe retir'd her ſelf.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.l: Sick of the Maid perhaps, becauſe ſhe fees
You Miſtriſs Bride, her School- and Play-fellow
So ſuddenly turned Wife.

sp.speaker: Franck.
sp.p: 'Twas ſhrewdly gueſt.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.l: Go finde her out: Fie Gentlemen, within
The Muſick playes unto the ſilent walls,
And no man there to grace it: when I was young,
At ſuch a Meeting I have ſo beſtir'd me,
Till I have made the pale Green-fickneſs Girls
Bluſh like the Rubie, and drop pearls apace
Down from their Ivory fore-heads: In thoſe days
I have cut Capers thus high. Nay, in Gentlemen,
And ſingle out the Ladies.

sp.speaker: Raym.
sp.p: Well adviſed. Nay Mrs. Bride, you ſhall along with us; for without you all's nothing.

sp.speaker: Anna.
sp.p: Willingly, with Mr. Bridegrooms leave.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: Oh my beſt Joy, this day I am your ſervant.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p:
True, this day; ſhe his, her whole life after, ſo it ſhould be: onely this day a Groom to do her ſervice, for which the full remainder of his age he may write Maſter. I ha ••
•• e it yet, and ſo I hope ſtill ſhall do. Siſter Luce, may I preſume my brother Franckford can ſay as much, and truly?

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: Sir, he may, I freely give him leave.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p:
Obſerve that brother, ſhe freely gives you leave;
But who gives leave, the Maſter or the ſervant?

sp.speaker: Franck.
sp.p: You'r pleaſant, and it becomes you well, but this day moſt; that having but one Daughter, have beſtowed her to your great hope and comfort.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: I have one: would you could ſay ſo, Siſter; but your barrenneſs hath given your husband freedom, if he pleaſe, to ſeek his paſtime elſewhere.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: Well, well brother, though you may taunt me that have never yet been bleſt with iſſue, ſpare my husband pray, for he may have a By-blow, or an Heir that you never heard of.

sp.speaker: Franck.
sp.p: Oh fie wife, make not my fault too publick.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: Yet himſelf keep within compaſs.

sp.speaker: Franck.
sp.p: If you love me, Sweet.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: Nay I have done.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: But if he have not, Wench, I would he had, the hurt I wiſh you both. Prithee, thine ear a little.

sp.speaker: Nurſe.
sp.p: Your boy grows up, and 'tis a chopping Lad, A man even in the Cradle.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Softly Nurſe:

sp.speaker: Nurſe.
sp.p: One of the forwardſt infants, how it will crow And chirrup like a Sparrow! I fear ſhortly it will breed teeth, you muſt provide him therefore a Corral, with a Whiſtle and a Chain.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: He ſhall have any thing.

sp.speaker: Nurſe.
sp.l: He's now quite out of Blankets.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: There's a Piece, provide him what he wants, onely good Nurſe prithee at this time be ſilent.

sp.speaker: Nurſe.
sp.p: A Charm to binde any Nurſes tongue that's living.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.l: Come, we are miſt among the younger Frye,
Gravity oft-times becomes the ſports of youth, eſpe • ially
At ſuch Solemnities, and it were ſin
Not in our Age to ſhow what we have bin.
sp.stage: Enter Leſsingham ſad, with a Letter in his hand.

sp.speaker: Leſſ.
sp.p:
Amicitia nihil dedit natura ma us nec rarius, So ſaith my Author. If then powerful Nature in all her bounties ſhowred upon mankinde, found none more rare and precious than this one we call Friendſhip, oh to what a Monſter would this trans-ſhape me, to be made that he to violate ſuch goodneſs! To kill any had been a ſad Injunction, but a Friend! nay, of all Friends the moſt approved! A Task, hell till this day could never parallel: And yet this woma • ha's a power of me beyond all
vertue, vertue, almoſt grace. What might her hidden purpoſe be in this? unleſs ſhe apprehend ſome fantaſi that no ſuch thing ha's being:—and as kinred and claims to Crowns are worn out of the world, ſo the name Friend? 'T may be 'twas her conceit. I have tryed thoſe that have profeſſed much for coin; nay ſometimes ſlighter courteſies, yet found 'em cold enough,—ſo perhaps ſhe, which makes her thus opinion'd.—If in the former, and therefore better days, 'twas held ſo rare, who knows but in theſe laſt and worſer times, it may be now with juſtice baniſht th' earth. I'm full of thoughts, and this my troubled breſt diſtemper'd with a thouſand fantaſies, ſomething I muſt reſolve. I'le firſt make proof if ſuch a thing there be; which having found, 'Twixt Love and Friendſhip 'twill be a brave Fight,
To prove in man which claims the greateſt right.
sp.stage: Enter Raymond, Euſtace, Lyonel, and Grover.

sp.speaker: Raym.
sp.l: What, Maſter Leſsingham!
You that were wont to be compos'd of mirth,
All ſpirit and fire.—Alacrity it ſelf, like the luſtre of a late bright ſhining Sun, now wrapt in clouds and darkneſs!

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.l: Prithee be merry,
Thy dulneſs ſads the half part of the houſe,
And deads that ſpirit which thou waſt wont to quicken,
And half ſpent to give Life too.

sp.speaker: Leſſ.
sp.l: Gentlemen, ſuch as have cauſe for ſport, I ſhall wiſh ever
To make of it the preſent benefit
While it exiſts.—Content is ſtill ſhort breathed,
When it was mine I did ſo. If now yours,
I pray make your beſt uſe on't.

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.l: Riddles and Paradoxes:
Come, come, ſome Crotchers come into thy pate,
And I will know the cauſe on't.

sp.speaker: Grov.
sp.p: So will I, or I proteſt ne're leave thee.

sp.speaker: Euſt.
sp.p: 'Tis a buſineſs proper to my ſelf,—one that concerns no ſecond perſon.

sp.speaker: Grov.
sp.p: How's that? not a friend?

sp.speaker: Leſſ.
sp.p: Why, is there any ſuch?

sp.speaker: Grov.
sp.p: Do you queſtion that? what do you take me for?

sp.speaker: Euſt.
sp.p:
I Sir, or me? 'Tis many moneths ago ſince we betwixt
us interchang'd that name, and of my part ne're broken.

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.p: Troth, nor mine.

sp.speaker: Raym.
sp.l: If you make queſtion of a Friend, I pray
Number not me the laſt in your accomp • ,
That would be crown'd in your opinion firſt.

sp.speaker: Leſſ.
sp.p: You all ſpeak nobly. But amongſt you all
Can ſuch a one be found?

sp.speaker: Raym.
sp.p: Not one amongſt us, but would be proud to wear the character of noble Friendſhip. In the name of which, and of all us here preſent, I intreat, expoſe to us the grief that troubles you.

sp.speaker: Leſſ.
sp.p: I ſhall, and briefly: If ever Gentleman ſunk beneath ſcandal, or his reputation never to be recovered, ſuffered, and for want of one whom I may call a Friend, then mine is now in danger.

sp.speaker: Raym.
sp.p: I'le redeem't, though with my lifes dear hazard.

sp.speaker: Euſt.
sp.p: I pray Sir, be to us open breaſted.

sp.speaker: Leſſ.
sp.p: Then 'tis thus: There is to be performed a Monamachy-Combat, or Duel, Time, Place, and Weapon agreed betwixt us. Had it toucht my ſelf, and my ſelf onely, I had then been happy; but I by compoſition am engag'd to bring with me my Second, and he too, not as the Law of Combat is, to ſtand aloof and ſee fair play, bring off his Friend, but to engage his perſon; both muſt fight, and either of them dangerous.

sp.speaker: Euſt.
sp.p: Of all things, I do not like this fighting.

sp.speaker: Leſſ.
sp.l: Now Gentlemen, of this ſo great a courteſie
I am at this inſtant meerly deſtitute.

sp.speaker: Raym.
sp.p: The time.

sp.speaker: Leſſ.
sp.p: By eight a clock to morrow.

sp.speaker: Raym.
sp.p: How unhappily things may fall out, I am juſt at that hour upon ſome late conceived Diſcontents, to atone me to my father, otherwiſe of all the reſt you had commanded me your Second, and your Servant.

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.p: Pray the Place?

sp.speaker: Leſſ.
sp.p: Callis-Sands.

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.p: It once was fatal to a friend of mine, and a near kinſman, for which I vowed then, and deeply too, never to ſee that ground: But if it had been elſewhere, one of them had before mine been worms-meat.

sp.speaker: Grov.
sp.p: What's the weapon?

sp.speaker: Leſſ.
sp.p: Single-ſword.

sp.speaker: Grov.
sp.p:
Of all that you could na •• ,
A thing I never practis'd,—Had it been Rapier—or that, and Ponyard, where men uſe rather ſleight than force, I had been then your Man; being young, I ſtrained the ſinews of my arm, ſince then to me 'twas never ſerviceable.

sp.speaker: Euſt.
sp.l: In troth Sir, had it been a money-matter,
I could have ſtood your friend, but as for ſighting
I was ever out at that.

sp.speaker: Leſſ.
sp.l: Well, farewel Gentlemen,
But where's the Friend in all this? tuſh, ſhe's wiſe,
And knows there's no ſuch thing beneath the moon:
I now applaud her judgement.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: Why how now friend, this Diſcontent which now
Is ſo unſeaſon'd, makes me queſtion what
I ne're durſt doubt before, your Love to me,
Doth it proceed from Envy of my Bliſs
Which this day crowns me with? Or have you been
A ſecret Rival in my happineſs?
And grieve to ſee me owner of thoſe Joys,
Which you could wiſh your own?

sp.speaker: Leſſ.
sp.l: Baniſh ſuch thoughts,
Or you ſhall wrong the trueſt faithful Friendſhip
Man e're could boaſt of, oh mine honor, Sir,
'Tis that which makes me wear this brow of ſorrow:
Were that free from the power of Calumny.
But pardon me, that being now a dying
Which is ſo near to man, if part we cannot
With pleaſant looks.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: Do but ſpeak the burthen, and I proteſt to take it off from you, and lay it on my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Leſſ.
sp.p: 'Twere a requeſt, impudence without bluſhing could not ask, it bears with it ſuch injury.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: Yet muſt I know't.

sp.speaker: Leſſ.
sp.p:
Receive it then.—But I intreat you ſir, not to imagine that I apprehend a thought to further my intent by you, from you 'tis leaſt ſuſpected.—'Twas my fortune to entertain a Quarrel with a Gentleman, the Field betwixt us challeng'd,—place and time, and theſe to be performed not without Seconds. I have rely'd on many ſeeming friends, but cannot bleſs my memory
with one dares venter in my Quarrel.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: Is this all?

sp.speaker: Leſſ.
sp.l: It is enough to make all temperature
Convert to fury.—Sir, my Reputation
(The life and ſoul of Honor) is at ſtake,
In danger to be loſt.—The word of Coward
Still printed in the name of Leſsingham.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: Not while there is a Bonvile.—May I live poor,
And die deſpiſed, not having one ſad friend
To wait upon my Hearſe, if I ſurvive
The ruine of that Honor.—Sir, the time?

sp.speaker: Leſſ.
sp.l: Above all ſpare me—for that once known,
You'l cancel this your promiſe, and unſay
Your friendly proffer.—Neither can I blame you,
Had you confirmed it with a thouſand Oathes,
The Heavens would look with mercy, not with juſtice
On your offence, ſhould you enfringe 'em all.
Soon after Sun-riſe upon Callis-ſands,
To morrow we ſhould meet—now to deferre
Time one half hour, I ſhould but forfeit all.
But Sir, of all men living, this alas
Concerns you leaſt;—For ſhall I be the man
To rob you of this nights felicity,
And make your Bride a Widow,—her ſoft bed
No witneſs of thoſe joys this night expects?

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: I ſtill preferre my friend before my pleaſure,
Which is not loſt for ever—but adjourned
For more mature employment.

sp.speaker: Leſſ.
sp.p: Will you go then?

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: I am reſolved I will.

sp.speaker: Leſſ.
sp.p: And inſtantly?

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: With all theſpeed celerity can make.

sp.speaker: Leſſ.
sp.p: You do not weigh thoſe inconveniences this Action meets with.—Your departure hence will breed a ſtrange diſtraction in your friends, diſtruſt of Love in your fair vertuous Bride, whoſe eyes perhaps may never more be bleſt with your dear ſight: ſince you may meet a grave, and that not amongſt your noble Anceſtors, but amongſt ſtrangers, almoſt enemies.

sp.speaker: Bon,
sp.l: This were enough to ſhake a weak reſolve,
It moves not me. Take horſe as ſecretly
As you well may: my Groom ſhall make mine ready▪
With all ſpeed poſſible, unknown to any.

sp.speaker: Leſſ.
sp.p: But Sir, the Bride.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Did you not ſee the Key that's to unlock my Carckanet and Bracelets? Now in troth I am afraid 'tis loſt.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: No Sweet, I ha't: I found it lye at random in your Chamber, and knowing you would miſs it, laid it by: 'tis ſafe I warrant you.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Then my fear's paſt: but till you give it back, my Neck and Arms are ſtill your Priſoners.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: But you ſhall finde they have a gentle Jaylor.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: So I hope. Within y'are much enquired of.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: Sweet, I follow. Dover?

sp.speaker: Leſſ.
sp.p: Yes, that's the place.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: If you be there before me, hire a Barque, I ſhall not fail to meet you.

sp.speaker: Leſſ.
sp.p: Was ever known a man ſo miſerably bleſt as I? I have have no ſooner found the greateſt good, man in this pilgrimage of Life can meet, but I muſt make the womb where 'twas conceived, the Tomb to bury it, and the firſt hour it lives,
The laſt it muſt breath? Yet there's a Fate
That ſways and governs above womans hate.

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.p:
A Younger Brother? 'tis a poor Calling (though not unlawful) very hard to live on; the elder fool inherits all the Lands, and we that follow Legacies of Wit, and get 'em when we can too. Why ſhould Law (if we be lawful and legitimate) leave us without an equal divident? Or why compels it not our Fathers elſe to ceaſe from getting, when they want to give? No ſure, our Mothers will ne're agree to that, they love to groan, although the Gallows eccho and groan together for us. From the firſt we travel forth, t'other's our journeys end. I muſt forward, to beg is out of my way, and borrowing
is out of date: The old road, the old high-way ' • muſt be, and I am in't, the place will ſerve for a yong beginner, for this is the firſt day I ſet ope ſhop; ſucceſs then ſweet L ••• rna, I have heard that Thieves adore thee for a Deity.
I would not purchaſe by thee, but to eat,
And 'tis too churliſh to deny me meat.
Soft, here may be a booty.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Horſ'd, ſayeſt thou?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Yes Miſtriſs, with Leſſingham.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Alack, I know not what to doubt or fear, I know not well whether't be well or ill: but ſure it is no cuſtom for the Groom to leave his Bride upon the Nuptial day. I am ſo yong and ignorant a Scholar, yes, and it proves ſo: I talk away perhaps that might be yet recovered. Prithee run, the fore-path may advantage thee to meet 'em, or the Ferry which is not two miles before, may trouble 'em until thou comeſt in ken, and if thou doſt, prithee enforce thy voice to overtake thine eyes, cry out, and crave for me but one word 'fore his departure. I will not ſtay him, ſay, beyond his pleaſure; nor rudely ask the cauſe, if he be willing to keep it from me. Charge him by all the love. But I ſtay thee too long. Run, run.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: If I had wings I would ſpread 'em now, Miſtriſs.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Ile make the beſt ſpeed after that I can,
Yet I am not well acquainted with the path:
My fears I fear me will miſguide me too.

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.p: There's good moveables I perceive, what ere the ready Coin be, who ever owns her, ſhe's mine now: the next ground has a moſt pregnant hollow for the purpoſe.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: I'm at a doubt already where I am.

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.p: Ile help you, Miſtriſs, well overtaken.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Defend me goodneſs. What are you?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: An honeſt man, I hope.

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.p: In ſome degrees hot, not altogether cold,
So far as rank poiſon, yet dangerous
As I may be dreſt: I am an honeſt thief.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Honeſt and Thief hold ſmall affinity, I never heard they were a kin before, pray Heaven I finde it now.

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.p: I tell you my name.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Then honeſt thief, ſince you have taught me ſo, for Ile enquire no other, uſe me honeſtly.

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.p: Thus then Ile uſe you: Firſt then to prove me honeſt, I will not violate your Chaſtity, (that's no part yet of my profeſſion) be you Wife or Virgin.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: I am both, Sir.

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.p: This then it ſeems ſhould be your Wedding-day, and theſe the hours of interim to keep you in that double ſtate. Come then, Ile be brief, for Ile not hinder your defired Hymen: You have about you ſome ſuperfluous Toys, which my lanck hungry pockets would contrive with much more profit, and more privacy; you have an idle Chain which keeps your Neck a Priſoner, a Mannacle I take it, about your wriſt too. If theſe prove Emblems of the combined Hemp to halter mine, the Fates take their pleaſure, theſe are ſet down to be your Ranſom, and there the Thief is proved.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: I will confeſs both, and the laſt forget; you ſhall be onely honeſt in this deed. Pray you take it, I intreat you to it, and then you ſteal 'em not.

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.p: You may deliver 'em.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Indeed I cannot: if you obſerve, Sir, they are both lock'd about me, and the Key I have not; happily you are furniſht with ſome inſtrument, that may unlooſe 'em.

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.l: No in troth, Lady, I am but a Freſh-man,
I never read further than this Book you ſee,
And this very day is my beginning too:
Theſe picking Laws I am to ſtudy yet.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Oh, do not ſhow me that, Sir, 'tis too frightful:
Good, hurt me not, for I do yield 'em freely:
Uſe but your hands, perhaps their ſtrength will ſerve
To tear 'em from me without much detriment,
Somewhat I will endure.

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.p: Well, ſweet Lady, y' are the beſt Patient for a young Phyſician, that I think e're was practis'd on. Ile uſe you as gently as I can, as I'm an honeſt Thief. No? wilt not do? do I hurt you, Lady?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Not much, Sir.

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.p: I'd be loath at all, I cannot do't.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Nay then you ſhall not, Sir. You a Thief,
And guard your ſelf no better? No further read?
Yet out in your own book? A bad Clerk, are you not?

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.p: I by Saint Nicholas, Lady, ſweet Lady.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Sir, I have now a Maſculine vigor, and will redeem my ſelf with purchaſe too. What money have you?

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.p: Not a croſs, by this fooliſh hand of mine.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: No money. 'Twere pity then to take this from thee: I know thou'lt uſe me ne're the worſe for this, take it agen, I know not how to uſe it: A frown had taken't from me, which thou hadſt not. And now hear and believe me, on my knees I make the Proteſtation, Forbear to take what violence and danger muſt diſſolve, if I forgo 'em now, I do aſſure you would not ſtrike my head off for my Chain, nor my hand for this, how to deliver 'em otherwiſe I know not; Accompany me back unto my houſe, 'tis not far off, by all the Vows which this day I have tyed unto my wedded husband, the honor yet equal with my Cradle puritie (if you will tax me) to the hoped joys the bleſſings of the bed, poſterity, or what ought elſe by woman may be pledg'd, I will deliver you in ready Coin, the full and deareſt eſteem of what you crave.

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.p: Ha, ready money is the prize I look for, it walks without ſuſpition any where, when Chains and Jewels may be ſtayed and call'd before the Conſtable: But,

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: But? Can you doubt? You ſaw I gave you my advantage up: Did you e're think a woman to be true?

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.p: Thought 's free. I have heard of ſome few, Lady, Very few indeed.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Will you adde one more to your belief?

sp.speaker: Roch
sp.p: They were fewer than the Articles of my Belief; therefore I have room for you, and will believe you. Stay: you'l ranſom your Jewels with ready Coin, ſo may you do, and then diſcover me.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Shall I reiterate the Vows I made
To this injunction, or new ones coyn?

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.p:
Neither, Ile truſt you: if you do deſtroy a Thief that never yet did Robbery, then farewel I, and mercy fall upon me. I knew one once fifteen years Courtier, owl'd, and he was buried
e're he took a Bribe • it may be my caſe in the worſer way. Come, you know your path back.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Yes, I ſhall guide you.

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.l: Your arm, Ile lead with greater dread than will.
Nor do you fear, tho in thiefs handling ſtill.
sp.stage: Enter two Boys, one with a childe in his arms.

sp.speaker: 1 Boy.
sp.p: I ſay 'twas fair play.

sp.speaker: 2 Boy.
sp.p: To ſnatch up ſtakes: I ſay you ſhould not ſay ſo, if the childe were out of mine arms.

sp.speaker: 1 Boy.
sp.p: I then thou'dſt lay about like a man, but the childe will not be out of thine arms this five years, and then thou haſt a prentiſhip to ſerve to a boy afterwards.

sp.speaker: 2 Boy.
sp.p: So ſir, you know you have the advantage of me.

sp.speaker: 1 Boy.
sp.p: I'm ſure you have the odds of me, you are two to one. But ſoft Jack who comes here? if a Point will make us friends, we'l not fall out.

sp.speaker: 2 Boy.
sp.p: Oh the pity, 'tis Gaffer Compaſs! They ſaid he was dead three years ago.

sp.speaker: 1 Boy.
sp.p: Did not he dance the Hobby-horſe in Hackney-Morrice once?

sp.speaker: 2 Boy.
sp.p: Yes, yes, at Green-gooſe Fayr, as honeſt and as poor a man.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Black-wall, ſweet Black-wall, do I ſee thy white cheeks again? I have brought ſome Brine from ſea for thee: tears that might be tyed in a True-love Knot, for they'r freſh ſalt indeed. Oh beautiful Black-wall! if Urfe my wife be living to this day, though ſhe die to morrow, ſweet Fates!

sp.speaker: 2 Boy.
sp.l: Alas, let's put him out of his dumps for pity ſake:
Welcome home, Gaffer Compaſs, welcome home, Gaffer.

sp.speaker: Compaſs.
sp.p: My pretty youths, I thank you. Honeſt Jack! what a little man art thou grown ſince I ſaw thee? Thou haſt got a child ſince, methinks.

sp.speaker: 2 Boy.
sp.p: I am fain to keep it, you ſee, whoſoever got it, Gaffer: it may be another mans caſe as well as mine.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Say'ſt true, Jack: and whoſe pretty knave is it?

sp.speaker: 2 Boy.
sp.p: One that I mean to make a younger brother if he live to't, Gaffer. But I can tell you news: You have a brave Boy of your own wifes: oh▪ is a ſhot to this • ig.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Have I Jack? Ile o • thee a dozen of Points for this news

sp.speaker: 2 Boy.
sp.p: Oh 'tis a chopping Boy! it cannot chuſe you know, Gaffer, it was ſo long a breeding.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: How long, Jack?

sp.speaker: 2 Boy.
sp.p: You know 'tis four year ago ſince you went to ſea, and your childe is but a Quarter old yet.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: What pl • guy boys are bred now adays?

sp.speaker: 1 Boy
sp.p: Pray Gaffer, how long may a childe be breeding before 'tis born?

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: That is as things are and prove, childe; the ſoyl has a great hand in't too, the Horizon, and the Cilme; theſe things you'l underſtand when you go to ſea. In ſome parts of London hard by, you ſhall have a Bride married to day, and brought to Bed within a moneth after, ſometimes within three weeks, a fortnight.

sp.speaker: 1 Boy.
sp.p: Oh horrible.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: True as I tell you Lads: in another place you ſhall have a couple of Drones, do what they ean, ſhift Lodgings, Beds, Bed-fellows, yet not a childe in ten years.

sp.speaker: 2 Boy.
sp.p: Oh pitiful.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Now it varies agen by that time you come at Wapping, Radcliff, Lymehouſe, and here with us at Black-wall, our children come uncertainly, as the winde ſerves: ſometimes here we are ſuppoſed to be away three or four year together, 'tis nothing ſo; we are at home and gone agen, when no body knows on't: if you'l believe me, I have been at Surrat as this day, I have taken the Long-boat (a fair Gale with me) been here a bed with my wife by twelve a Clock at night, up and gone agen i'th morning and no man the wiſer, if you'l believe me.

sp.speaker: 2 Boy.
sp.p: Yes, yes Gaffer, I have thought ſo many times that you or ſomebody elſe have been at home, I lye at next wall, and I have heard a noiſe in your chamber all night long.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Right, why that was I, yet thou never ſawſ • me.

sp.speaker: 2 Boy.
sp.p: No indeed, Gaffer.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: No, I warrant thee, I was a thouſand leagues off e're thou wert up. But Jack, I have been loath to ask all this while for diſcomforting my ſelf, how does my wife? is ſhe living?

sp.speaker: 2 Boy.
sp.p:
Oh never better, Gaffer, never ſo luſty, and truly ſhe wears better clothes than ſhe was wont in your days, eſpecially on Holidays, fair Gowns, brave Petticoats, and fine Smocks, they ſay that have ſeen 'em; and ſome of the neighbors reports
that they were taken up at London.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Like enough: they muſt be paid for, Jack:

sp.speaker: 2 Boy.
sp.p: And good reaſon, Gaffer.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Well Jack, thou ſhalt have the honor on't, go tell my wife the joyful tidings of my return.

sp.speaker: 2 Boy.
sp.p: That I will, for ſhe heard you were dead long ago.

sp.speaker: 1 Boy.
sp.p: Nay ſir, Ile be as forward as you, by your leave.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.l: Well wife, if I be one of the Livery, I thank thee,
The Hornets are a great Company, there may be
An Alderman amongſt us one day, 'tis but changing
Our Copy, and then we are no more to be called
By our old Brother-hood.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Oh my ſweet Compaſs, art thou come agen?

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.l: Oh Urſe, give me leave to ſhed, the fountain of Love
Will have their courſe; though I cannot ſing at firſt ſight,
Yet I can cry before I ſee. I am new come into the world,
And children cry before they laugh a fair while.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: And ſo thou art, ſweet Compaſs, new born indeed; for Rumor laid thee out for dead long ſince, I never thought to ſee this face agen. I heard thou wert div'd to th' bottom of the ſea, and taken up a Lodging in the Sands, never to come to Black-wall agen.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: I was going indeed wife, but I turn'd back: I heard an ill report of my neighbors, Sharks and Sword-fiſhes, and the like, whoſe companies I did not like: come kiſs my tears now ſweet Urſe, ſorrow begins to ebb.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: A thouſand times welcome home, ſweet Compaſs.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: An Ocean of thanks, and that will hold 'em: and Urſe, how goes all at home? or cannot all go yet? Lanck ſtill? will 't never be full Sea at our Wharf?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Alas, husband.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: A laſs or a lad, wench, I ſhould be glad of both: I did look for a pair of Compaſſes before this day.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: And you from home?

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: I from home? why though I be from home, and other of our neighbors from home, it is not fit all ſhould be from home, ſo the town might be left deſolate, and our neighbors of Bowe might come further from the Itacus, and inhabit here.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: I'm glad y'are merry, ſweet husband.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Merry? nay, Ile be merrier yet, why ſhould I • e ſorry? I hope my boy 's well, is he not? I lookt for another by this time.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: What boy, husband?

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: What boy? why the boy I got when I came home in the Cock-boat one night, about a year ago? you have not forgotten't, I hope? I think I left behinde for a boy, and a boy I muſt be anſwer'd: I'm ſure I was not drunk, it could be no girl.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Nay then I do perceive my fault is known. Dear man, your pardon.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Pardon. Why thou haſt not made away my boy, haſt thou? Ile hang thee if there were ne're a whore in London more, if thou haſt hurt but his little toe.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Your long abſence, with rumor of your death,
After long bettery I was ſurprized.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Surprized? I cannot blame thee: Black-wall, if it were double black-walled, can't hold out always, no more than Lymehouſe, or Chadwell, or the ſtrongeſt Suburbs about London, and when it comes to that, woe be to the City too.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Purſued by gifts and promiſes I yielded: Conſider huſband, I am a woman, neither the firſt nor laſt of ſuch Offenders, 'tis true, I have a childe.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Ha, you? and what ſhall I have then I pray? will not you labor for me as I ſhall do for you? Becauſe I was out o'th way when 'twas gotten, ſhall I looſe my ſhare? There's better Law amongſt the Players yet; for a fellow ſhall have his ſhare though he do not play that day: if you look for any part of my fours Years wages, I will have half the boy.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: If you can forgive me, I ſhall be joyed at it.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Forgive thee, for what? for doing me a pleaſure? and what is he that would ſeem to father my childe?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: A man ſir, whom in better courteſies we have been beholding too: the Merchant, Mr. Franckford.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Ile acknowledge no other courteſies: for this I am beholding to him, and I would requite it if his wife were young enough. Though he be one of our Merchants at Sea, he ſhall give me leave to be Owner at home. And where 's my boy? ſhall I ſee him?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: He's nu • ſt at Bed • al-green: 'tis now too late,
To morrow Ile bring you to it, if you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.l: I would thou couldſt bring me another by to morrow.
Come, we'l eat and to bed, and if a fair Gale come,
We'l hoiſt ſheets, and ſet forwards.
Let fainting fools ſie fick upon their ſcorns,
Ile teach a Cuckold how to hide his horns.
sp.stage: Enter Woodroff, Franckford, Raymond, Euſtace, Grover, Lyonel, Clare, Luce.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: This wants a preſident, that a Bridegroom ſhould ſo diſcreet and decently obſerve his Forms, Poſtures, all cuſtomary Rites belonging to the Table, and then hide himſelf from his expected wages in the bed.

sp.speaker: Franck.
sp.p: Let this be forgotten too, that it remains not a firſt example.

sp.speaker: Raym.
sp.p: Keep it amongſt us, leſt it beget too much unfruitful ſorrow: moſt likely 'tis that love to Leſſingham hath faſtened on him, we all denied.

sp.speaker: Euſt.
sp.p: 'Tis more certain than likely. I know 'tis ſo.

sp.speaker: Grov.
sp.p: Conceal then: the event may be well enough.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.l: The Bride my daughter, ſhe's hidden too:
This laſ • hour ſhe hath not been ſeen with us.

sp.speaker: Raym.
sp.p: Perhaps they are together.

sp.speaker: Euſt.
sp.p: And then we make too ſtrict an inquiſition, under correction of fair modeſty, ſhould they be ſtoln away to bed together, what would you ſay to that?

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.l: I would ſay, Speed 'em well,
And if no worſe news comes, Ile never weep for't.
How now, haſt thou any tidings?

sp.speaker: Nurſe.
sp.p: Yes forſooth, I have tidings.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Of any one that's loſt?

sp.speaker: Nurſe.
sp.p: Of one that's found agen, forſooth.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Oh, he was loſt, it ſeems then?

sp.speaker: Franck.
sp.p: This tidin • s comes to me, I gueſs Sir.

sp.speaker: Nurſe.
sp.p: Yes truly does it, ſir.

sp.speaker: Raym.
sp.p: I, has old Lads work for young Nurſes?

sp.speaker: Euſt.
sp.p: Yes, when they groan towards their ſecond infancy.

sp.speaker: Clare.
sp.p:
I fear my ſelf moſt guilty for the abſence of the Bridegroom:
what our wills will do 〈…〉 he adi ••• peeviſhneſs, to bring out 〈◊〉 diſcre •••••
••
〈◊〉 ? Leſſingham's miſtaken, quite out o'th way of my purpoſe too.

sp.speaker: Franck.
sp.p: Return'd?

sp.speaker: Nurſe.
sp.p: And all diſcover'd.

sp.speaker: Franck.
sp.p: A fool rid him further off. Let him nor Come near the child.

sp.speaker: Nurſe.
sp.p: Nor ſee't, if it be your charge.

sp.speaker: Franck.
sp.p: It is, and ſtrictly.

sp.speaker: Nurſe.
sp.p:
To morrow morning, as I hear, he purpoſeth to come to
• ed • al-green, his wi • e with him.

sp.speaker: Franck.
sp.p:
He ſhall be met there; yet if he fore-ſt ••• my co •
ing, keep the childe ſafe.

sp.speaker: Nurſe.
sp.p: If he be the earlier up, he ſhall arive at the proverb.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: So, ſo, there's ſome good luck yet,
The Bride 's in ſight agen.

sp.speaker: Anna.
sp.p:
Father, and Gentlemen all, beſeech you entr ••• this Gentleman with all courreſie, he is a loving kinſman of my
•••
viles, that kindly came to 〈◊〉 our Wedding; but a • the day falls out, you ſee 〈◊〉
▪ I perſon ••• both Groom and Bride; onely your help to make this welcome better.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Moſt dea • ly.

sp.speaker: Raym.
sp.p: To all, aſſure you ſir.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: But where's the Bridegroom, Girl? We are all at a non-plus here, at a ſtand, quite out, the Muſick ceaſed, a • d dancing ••• bated, not a light beel amongſt us; my Couſin 〈◊〉 as cloudy here as on a waſhing-day.

sp.speaker: Clare.
sp.p: It is becauſe you will not dance with me,
I ſhould then ſhake it off.

sp.speaker: Anna.
sp.p: 'Tis I have cauſe to be the ſad one now, if any be: but I have queſtion'd with my meditations, and they have • end'red well and comfortably to the worſt fear I found: Suppoſe this day he had long ſince appointed to his foe to meet, and fetch a Reputation from him (which is the deareſt Jewel unto man) Say he do fight, I know his goodneſs ſuch, that all thoſe Powers that love it are his guard, and ill cannot beride him.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Prithee peace, thou'lt make us all Cowards to •• ar a woman inſtruct ſo valiantly. Come, the Muſick, Ile dance •• y ſelf rather than thus put down, what, I am ri • e a little yet.

sp.speaker: Anna.
sp.p: Onely this Gentleman, pray you be free in welcome too, I tell you I was in a fear when firſt I ſaw him.

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.p: Ha? ſhe'l tell.

sp.speaker: Anna.
sp.p: I had quite loſt my way in my firſt amazement, but he ſo fairly came to my recovery, in his kinde conduct, gave me ſuch loving comforts to my fears: ('twas he inſtructed me in what I ſpake) and many better than I have told you yet, you ſhall hear more anon.

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.p: So, ſhe will out with 't.

sp.speaker: Anna.
sp.p: I muſt, I ſee, ſupply both places ſtill: Come, when I have ſeen you back to your pleaſure, I will return to you, Sir: we muſt diſcourſe more of my Bonvile yet.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: A noble Bride 'faith.

sp.speaker: Clare.
sp.p: You have your wiſhes, and you may be merry, Mine have over-gone me.

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.p: It is the tremblingſt trade to be a Thief, h'ad need have all the world bound to the peace, beſides the buſhes, and the phanes of houſes; every thing that moves he goes in fear of 's life on. A furr-gown'd Cat, and meet her in the night, ſhe ſtares with a Conſtables eye upon him; and every Dog, a Watch-man; a black Cowe and a Calf with a white face after her, ſhows like a ſurly Juſtice and his Clerk; and if the Baby go but to the bag, 'tis ink and paper for a Mittimus: Sure I ſhall never thrive on't, and it may be I ſhall need take no care, I may be now at my journeys end, or but the Goals diſtance, and ſo to' th t' other place: I truſt a woman with a ſecret worth a hanging, is that well? I could finde in my heart to run away yet. And that were baſe too, to run from a woman; I can lay claim to nothing but her Vows, and they ſhall ſtrengthen me.

sp.speaker: Anna.
sp.p: See ſir, my promiſe, there's twenty Pieces, the full value I vow, of what they coſt.

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.p: Lady, do not trap me like a Sumpter-horſe, and then ſpur-gall me till I break my winde: if the Conſtable be at the door, let his fair ſtaff appear, perhaps I may corrupt him with this Gold.

sp.speaker: Anna.
sp.p: Nay? then if you-miſtruſt me: Father, Gentlemen, Mr. Raymond, Euſtnce.
sp.stage: Enter all as before, and a Saylor-

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: How now, what's the matter, Girl?

sp.speaker: Anna.
sp.p: For ſhame will you bid your Kinſman welcome: No one but I will lay a hand on him,

Leave him alone, and all a revelli ••
▪

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Oh, is that it. Welcome, welcome heartily, I thought the Bridegroom had been return'd. But I have news, Annabel: this fellow brought it. Welcome Sir, why you tremble methinks, Sir.

sp.speaker: Anna.
sp.p: Some agony of anger 'tis, believe it, his entertainment is ſo cold and feeble.

sp.speaker: Raym.
sp.p: Pray be cheer'd, Sir.

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.p: I'm wondrous well, ſir, 'twas the Gentlemans miſtake.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: 'Twas my hand ſhook belike, then you muſt pardon Age, I was ſtiffer once. But as I was ſaying, I ſhould by promiſe ſee the Sea to morrow, 'tis meant for Phyſick as low as Lee or Margets: I have a Veſſel riding forth, Gentlemen, 'tis called the God-ſpeed too, • hough I ſay't, a brave one, well and richly fraughted; and I can tell you ſhe carries a Letter of Mart in her mouth too, and twenty roaring Boys on both ſides on her, Star-board and Lar-board. What ſay you now, to make you all Adventurers? you ſhall have fair dealing, that Ile promiſe you.

sp.speaker: Raym.
sp.p: A very good motion, ſir I begin, there's my ten pieces.

sp.speaker: Euſt.
sp.p: I ſecond 'em with theſe.

sp.speaker: Grov.
sp.p: My ten in the third place.

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.p: And Sir, if you refuſe not a proffet'd love, take my ten Pieces with you too.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Yours; above all the reſt, Sir.

sp.speaker: Anna.
sp.p: Then make 'em above, venter ten more.

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.p: Alas Lady, 'tis a younger brothers portion, and all in one Bottom.

sp.speaker: Anna.
sp.p: At my encouragement, Sir, your credit (if you want Sir) ſhall not ſit down under that ſum return'd.

sp.speaker: Eoch.
sp.p: With all m • heart, Lady. There Sir: So ſhe has fiſht for her Gold back, and caught it; I am no thief now.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: I ſhall make here a pretty Aſſurance.

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.p: Sir, I ſhall have a ſuit to you.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: You are likely to obtain it then, Sir.

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.p: That I may keep you company to Sea, and attend you back; I am a little travell'd.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: And heartily thank you too, ſir.

sp.speaker: Anna.
sp.p: Why, that's well ſaid. Pray you be merry though your Kinſman be abſent, I am 〈◊〉 , the worſt part of him, yet that ſhall ſerve to give you welco • e: to morrow may ſhow you what this night will not, and be full aſſured,
Unleſs your twenty Pieces be ill • ent,
Nothing ſhall give you cauſe of Diſcontent.
There's ten more, Sir.

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.p: Why ſhould I fear? Fouter o • 't, Ile be merry now ſpite of the Hang-man.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: WE are firſt i'th field: I think your Enemy is ſtaid at Dover, or ſome other Port, we hear not of his landing.

sp.speaker: Leſſ.
sp.p: I am confident he is come over.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: You look methinks freſh coloured.

sp.speaker: Leſſ.
sp.p: Like a red Morning, friend, that ſtill foretels a ſtormy day to follow • : But methinks now I obſerve your face, that you look pale, there's death in't already.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: I could chide your error, do you take me for a Coward? A Coward is not his own friend, much leſs can he be another mans. Know, Sir, I am come hither to inſtruct you by my generous example, to kill your enemy, whoſe name as yet I never queſtion'd.

sp.speaker: Leſſ.
sp.p: Nor dare I name him yet, for d • -heartning you.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: I do begin to doubt the goodneſs of your Quarrel.

sp.speaker: Leſſ.
sp.p: Now you hav't; for I proteſt that I muſt fight with one from whom in the whole courſe of our acquaintance, I never did receive the leaſt injury.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: It may be the forgetful Wine beg • t ſome ſudden blow, and thereupon 'tis Challenge, howe're you are engaged; and for my part I will not, take your courſe, my unlucky friend, to ſay your Conſcience grows pale and heartleſs, maintaining a bad Cauſe: fight as Lawyers plead; who gain the beſt of reputation when they can fetch a bad Cauſe ſmoothly off: you are in, and 〈◊〉 through.

sp.speaker: Leſſ.
sp.p: Oh my friend, the nobleſt ever man had: when 〈◊◊〉 threw me upon this buſineſs, I made trr • d of divers had p ••• eſt to me much love, and found their friendſhip like the effects that kept our company together, Wine and Riot: giddy and ſinking I had found 'em oft, brave Seconds at pluralities of Healths, but when it came to'th proof, my Gentlemen appeared to me as promiſing and failing as cozening Lotteries; but then I found this Jewel worth a thouſand Counterfeits: I did but name my Engagement, and you flew unto my ſuccor with that chearfulneſs, as a great General haſtes to a Battel, when that the chief of the adverſe part is a man glorious, but of ample fame: you left your Bridal-bed to finde your Death-bed, and herein you moſt nobly expreſt, that the affection 'tween two loyal friends is far beyond the love of man to woman, and is more near allied to eternity. What better friends part could be ſhowed i'th world? it tranſcends all! My father gave me life, but you ſtand by my honor when 'tis falling, and nobly under-propt it with your ſword. But now you have done me all this ſervice, how? how ſhall I requite this? how return my grateful recompence for all this love? For it am I come hither with full purpoſe to kill you.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: Ha?

sp.speaker: Leſſ.
sp.p: Yes: I have no oppoſite i'th would but your ſelf: There, read the Warrant for your death.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: 'Tis a womans hand.

sp.speaker: Leſſ.
sp.p: And 'tis a bad hand too: the moſt of 'em ſpeak fair, write foul, mean worſe.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: Kill me! away, you jeſt.

sp.speaker: Leſſ.
sp.p: Such jeſt as your ſharp-witted Gallants uſe to utter, and looſe their friends; Read there how I am fettered in a womans proud Command: I do Love madly, and muſt do madly: deadlieſt Hellebore or vomit of a To • d is qualified poyſon to the malice of a woman.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: And kill that friend? Strange!

sp.speaker: Leſſ
sp.p: You may ſee, Sir, although the Tenure by which Land was held in Villenage be quite extinct in England, yet you have women there at this day living, make a number of ſlayes.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: And kill that friend? She mocks you upon my life, ſhe does Equivocate: her meaning is; you cheriſh in your breaſt either ſelf-love, 〈◊〉 pride, as your beſt friend, and ſhe wiſhes you'd kill that.

sp.speaker: Leſſ.
sp.p:
Sure her Command is more bloody; for ſhe loathes me,
and has put, as ſhe imagines, this impoſſible task, for ever to be quit and free from me; but ſuch is the violence of my affection, that I muſt undergo it. Draw your ſword, and guard your ſelf, though I fight in fury, I ſhall kill you in cold blood, for I proteſt 'tis done in heart-ſorrow.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: Ile not fight with you, for I have much advantage; the truth is, I wear a privy Coat.

sp.speaker: Leſſ.
sp.p: Prithee put it off then, if then bee'ſt manly.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: The defence I mean, is the juſtice of my Cauſe that would guard me, and fly to thy deſtruction: what confide •• e thou weareſt in a bad cauſe, I am likely to kill thee if I fight, and then you fail to effect your Mrs. bidding, or to enjoy the fruit of 't; I have ever wiſht thy happineſs, and vow I now ſo much affect it in compaſſion of my friends ſorrow, make thy way to it.

sp.speaker: Leſſ.
sp.p: That were a cruel Murder.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: Believ't 'tis ne're intended otherwiſe, when 'tis a womans bidding.

sp.speaker: Leſſ.
sp.p: Oh the neceſſity of my fate.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: You ſhed tears.

sp.speaker: Leſſ.
sp.p: And yet muſt on in my cruel purpoſe: a Judge methinks looks lovelyeſt when he weeps, pronouncing of deaths Sentence: how I ſtagger in my reſolve! guard thee, for I came hither to do, and not to ſuffer; wilt not yet be perſwaded to defend thee? turn the point, advance it from the ground above thy head, and let it underprop thee otherwiſe, in a bold reſiſtance.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: Stay. Thy injunction was, thou ſhouldſt kill thy friend.

sp.speaker: Leſſ.
sp.p: It was.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: Obſerve me, he wrongs me moſt, ought to offend me leaſt, and they that ſtudy man, ſay of a friend, there's nothing in the world that's harder found, nor ſooner loſt: thou cameſt to kill thy friend, and thou mayeſt brag thou haſt don't; for here for ever all friendſhip dyes between us, and my heart for bringing forth any effects of love, ſhall be as barren to thee as this ſand we tread on; cruel, and inconſtant as the Sea that beats upon this Beach. We now are ſevered: thus haſt thou ſlain thy friend, and ſatisfied what the Witch thy Mrs. bad thee. Go and report that thou haſt ſlain thy friend.

sp.speaker: Leſſ.
sp.p: I am ſerved right.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: And now that I do ceaſe to be thy friend, 〈◊〉 will fight with thee as thine enemy, I came not over idly to do nothing.

sp.speaker: Leſſ.
sp.p: Oh friend!

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: Friend? The naming of that word ſhall be the quarrel. What do I know but that thou loveſt my wife, and f • ind'ſt this plot to divide me from her 〈◊〉 , and that this Letter here is counterfeit? Will you advanc • Sir.

sp.speaker: Leſſ.
sp.p: Not a blow; 'twould appear ill in either of us to fight: in you unmanly; for believe it Sir, you have diſarmed me already, done away all power of reſiſtance in me, it would ſhow beaſtly to do wrong to the dead: to me you ſay, you are dead for ever, loſt on Callis-ſands, by the cruelty of a woman; yet remember you had a noble friend, whoſe love to you ſhall continue after death: ſhall I go over in the ſame Barque with you?

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: Not for you town of Callis, you know 'tis dangerous living at Sea, with a dead body.

sp.speaker: Leſſ.
sp.p: Oh you mock me, may you enjoy all your noble wiſhes.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: And may you finde a better friend then I, and better keep him.
sp.stage: Enter Nurſe, Compaſs, and his Wife.

sp.speaker: Nurſe.
sp.p: Indeed you muſt pardon me, Goodman Compaſs, I have no authority to deliver, no not 〈◊〉 let you ſee the Childe; to tell you true, I have command unto the contrary.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Command. From whom?

sp.speaker: Nurſe.
sp.p: By the father of it.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: The father: Who am I?

sp.speaker: Nurſe.
sp.p: Not the father ſure. The Civil Law has found it otherwiſe.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: The Civil Law: why then the Uncivil Law ſhall make it mine agen; Ile be as dreadful as a Shrov • -tueſday to thee, I will tear thy Cottage but I will ſee my Childe.

sp.speaker: Nurſe.
sp.p: Speak but half ſo much agen, Ile call the Conſtable, and lay Burglary to thy charge.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: My good husband, be patient. And prithee Nurſe let him ſee the Childe.

sp.speaker: Nurſe.
sp.p: Indeed I dare not: the father firſt delivered me the Childe, he pays me well, and weekly for my pains, and to his uſe I keep it.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Why thou white Baſtard-breeder, is not this the mother?

sp.speaker: Nurſe.
sp.p: Yes, I grant you that.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Doſt thou? and I grant it too: And is not the Childe mine own then by the wifes Coppy-hold?

sp.speaker: Nurſe.
sp.p: The Law muſt try that.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Law? Doſt think Ile be but a Father in Law? all the Law betwixt Black-wall and Tuttle-ſtreet, and there's a pretty deal, ſhall not keep it from me mine own fleſh and blood? who does uſe to get my children but my ſelf?

sp.speaker: Nurſe.
sp.p: Nay, you muſt look to that, I ne're knew you get any.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Never? put on a clean Bmock and try me, if thou dareſt, three to one I get a Baſtard on thee to morrow morning between one and three.

sp.speaker: Nurſe.
sp.p: Ile ſee thee hangd firſt.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: So thou ſhalt too.

sp.speaker: Nurſe.
sp.p: Oh here's the father, now pray talk with him.

sp.speaker: Franck.
sp.p: Good morrow Neighbor: morrow to you both.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Both? Morrow to you and your wife too.

sp.speaker: Franck.
sp.p: I would ſpeak calmly with you.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: I know what belongs to a Calm and a Storm too. A cold word with you: You have tyed your Mare in my ground.

sp.speaker: Franck.
sp.p: No, twas my Nag.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: I will cut off your Nags tayl, and make his rump make Hair-buttons, if e're I take him there agen.

sp.speaker: Franck.
sp.p: Well ſir, but to the Main.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Main. Yes, and Ile clip his Main too, and crop his ears too, do you mark? and back gaul him, and ſpur-gaul him, do you note? And ſlit his Noſe, do you ſmell me now, Sir? Unbritch his Barrel, and diſcharge his Bullets: Ile gird him till he ſtinks, you ſmell me now I'm ſure.

sp.speaker: Franck.
sp.p: You are too rough neighbor, to maintain.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Maintain? you ſhall not maintain no childe of mine, my wife does not beſtow her labor to that purpoſe,

sp.speaker: Franck.
sp.p: You are too ſpeedy: I will not maintain

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: No marry ſhall you not.

sp.speaker: Franck.
sp.p: The deed to be lawful: I have repented it, and to the Law given ſatisfaction, my purſe has paid for't.

sp.speaker: Bemp.
sp.p: Your purſe: 'twas my wifes purſe. You brought in the Coin indeed, but it was found baſe and counterfeit.

sp.speaker: Franck.
sp.p: I would treat colder with you, if you be pleaſed.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p:
Pleaſed? yes I am pleaſed well enough, ſ •• ve me ſo ſtill: I am going agen to ſea one of theſe days, you know where I dwell, yet you'l but looſe your labor, get as many children as
you can, you ſhall keep none of them, Franck. You are mad.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: If I be horn-mad, what's that to you?

sp.speaker: Franck.
sp.p: I leave off milder phraſe, and then tell you plain you are a

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: A what? what am I?

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: A Coxcomb.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: A Coxcomb? I knew 'twould begin with a C.

sp.speaker: Franck.
sp.p: The childe is mine, I am the father of it; As it is paſt the deed, 'tis paſt the ſhame, I do acknowledge, and will enjoy it.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Yes, when you can get it agen, is it not my wifes labor? I'm ſure ſhe's the mother, you may be as far off the father as I am; for my wife's acquainted with more Whore-maſters beſides your ſelf, and crafty Merchants too.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: No indeed husband, to make my offence both leaſt and moſt, I knew no other man, he's the begetter, but the childe is mine, I bred and bore it, and I will not lo ••• it.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: The childe's my husbands, Dame, and he muſt have it: I do allow my ſufferance to the deed, in ſien I never yet was fruitful to him, and in my barrenneſs excuſe my wrong.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Let him dung his own ground better at home, then if he plant his Reddiſh roots in my garden, Ile eat 'em with bread and Salt, though I get no Mutt on to 'em; what tho your husband lent my wife your diſtaff, ſhall not the yarn be mine▪ Ile have the head, let him carry the ſpindle home agen.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: Forebear more words, then let the Law try it: mean time Nurſe keep the childe, and to keep it better here take more pay beforehand. There's money for thee.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: There's money for me too, keep it for me, Nurſe: give him both thy dugs at once: I pay for thy right dug.

sp.speaker: Nurſ.
sp.p: I have two hands you ſee, Gentlemen this does but ſhow how the law will hamper you: even thus you muſt be uſed.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: The law ſhall ſhow which is the worthier Gender: a School-boy can do't.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p:
Ile whip that School-boy that declines the childe from my wife and her heirs: do not I know my wifes caſe the Genetive Caſe, and that's Huju •
as great a caſe as can be.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: Well, fare you well, we ſhall meet in another place. Come Luce

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p:
Meet her in the ſame place agen if you dare, and do your worſt: muſt we go to 〈◊〉 our Childrennow a days? No
marvel if the Lawyers grow rich; but e're the Law ſhall have a Lymb, a Leg, a Joynt, a Nayl,
I will ſpend more then a whole childe in getting,
Some win by play, and others by, by betting.
sp.stage: Enter Raymond, Euſtace, Lyonel, Grover, Annabel, Clare.

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.p: Whence was that Letter ſent?

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.p: From Dover▪ Si •

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.p: And does that ſatisfie you what was the cauſe of his going over?

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.p: It does: yet had he onely ſent this it had bin ſufficient.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.p: Why, what's that?

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.p: His Will, wherein he has eſtated me in all his land.

sp.speaker: Euſt.
sp.p: He's gone to fight.

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.p: Leſſinghams ſecond certain.

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.p: And I am loſt, loſt in't for ever.

sp.speaker: Clare.
sp.p: Oh fool Leſſingham, thou haſt miſtook my injunction utterly, utterly miſtook it, and I am mad, ſtark mad with my own thoughts, not knowing what event their going or'e will come too; 'tis too late now for my tongue to cry my heart mercy, would I could be ſenceleſs till I hear of their return: I fear me both are loſt.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.p: Who ſhould it be Leſſinghams gone to fight with?

sp.speaker: Euſt.
sp.p: Faith I cannot poſſibly conjecture.

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.p: Miſerable creature! a Maid, a Wife, and Widow in the compaſs of two days.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.p: Are you ſad too?

sp.speaker: Clare.
sp.p: I am not very well, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.p: I muſt put life in you.

sp.speaker: Clare.
sp.p: Let me go, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.p: I do love you in ſpight of your heart.

sp.speaker: Clare.
sp.p: Believe it there was never a fitter time to expreſs it; for my heart has a great deal of ſpight in't.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.p: I will diſcourſe to you fine fancies.

sp.speaker: Clare.
sp.p: Fine fooleries, will you not?

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.p: By this hand I love you, and will court you.

sp.speaker: Clare.
sp.p: Fie, you can command your tongue, and I my ears to hear you no further.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.p: On my reputation, ſhe's off o'th hindges ſtrangely▪
sp.stage: Ent. Woodroff. Rochfeild▪ and a ſaylor.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Daughter, good news.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: What is my husband heard of?

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p:
That's not the buſineſs; but you have here a Couſin you may be mainly proud of, an I am ſorry 'tis by you • h •••• nds kindred, not your own, that we mig •• boaſt to have ſo brave a man in
our Allyance.

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.p: What ſo ſoon return'd? you have made but a ſhort voyage howſoever you are to me moſt welcome.

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.p: Lady thanks, 'tis you have made me your own creature, of all my being fortunes and poor fame, if I have purchas'd any, and of which I no way boaſt, n̄ext the high providence, you have bin the ſole creatreſs.

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.p: Oh deer Couſin, you are grateful above merit, what occaſion drew you ſo ſoon from Sea?.

sp.speaker: Wood
sp.p: Such an occaſion, as I may bleſs Heaven for, you thank their bounty, and all of us be joyful.

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.p: Tell us how.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Nay daughter, the diſcourſe will beſt appear in his relation, where he fails, Ile help.

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.p: Not to moleſt your patience with recital of every vain, and needleſs Circumſtance, 'twas briefly thus: Scarce having reacht to Margets, bound on our voyage, ſuddenly in view appeared to us three Spaniſh men of War, theſe having ſpied the Engliſh Croſs advance, ſalute us with a piece to have us ſtrike, ours better ſpirited and no way daunted, at their unequal oddes, though but one bottom, returned 'em fire for fire: the fight begins, and dreadful on the ſudden, ſtill they proffered to board us, ſtill we bravely beat 'em off.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: But daughter, mark the Event.

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.p: Sea room we got, our ſhip being ſwift of ſayl, it helpt us much, yet two unfortunate ſhot, one ſtruck the Captains head off, and the other with an unlucky ſplinter laid the Maſter dead on the hatches; all our ſpirits then failed us.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Not all, you ſhall hear further, daughter.

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.p: For none was left to manage, nothing now was talkt of but to yeild up ſhip and goods, and mediate for our peace.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Nay Couſ. proceed.

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.p: Excuſe me, I intreat you, for what's more, hath already paſt my memory.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: But mine it never can: Then he ſtood up, and with his oratory made us agen to recollect our ſpirits ſo late dejected.

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.p: Pray Sir.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p:
Ile ſpeak't out; by unite conſent then the command was his, and 'twas his place now to beſtir him, down he went below,
and put the Lin-ſtocks in the Gunners hands, they ply their ordinance bravely, then agen up to the decks; courage is there renewed, fear now not found amongſt us: within leſs then four hours fight two of their ſhips were ſunk, both foundered, and ſoon ſwallowed: not long after the three begins to wallow, lyes on the Lee to ſtop her leakes, then boldly we come on, boarded and took her, and ſhe's now our prize.

sp.speaker: Sayl.
sp.p: Of this we were eye witneſs.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: And many more brave boys of us, beſides my ſelf for one; never was, Gentlemen, a Sea fight better mannaged.

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.p: Thanks to Heaven we have ſaved our own, dammaged the enemy, and to our Nations glory, we bring home honor and profit.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: In which Couſin Rochfeild, you as a venturer have a double ſhare, beſides the name of Captain, and in that a ſecond benefit, but moſt of all, way to more great employment.

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.p: Thus your bounty hath been to me a bleſſing.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.p: Sir, we are all indebted to your valor, this beginning may make us of ſmall venturers, to become hereafter wealthy Merchants.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Daughter and Gentlemen, this is the man was born to to make us all, come enter, enter; we will in and feaſt, he's in the Bridegrooms abſence my chief gueſt.

div.head: ACT. 4. SCENE 1.
div.stage: Enter Compaſs, Wife, Lyonel, and Pettifog the Attorney, and one Boy.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: THree Tuns do you call this Tavern? it has a good neighbor of Guild-hall, Mr. Pettifog. Show a room boy.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Welcome Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: What? art thou here Hodge!

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: I am glad you are in health, ſir.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: This was the honeſt Crack-roap firſt gave me tidings of my wifes fruitfulneſs. Art bound Prentice?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Mayeſt thou long jumble Baſtard moſt artificially, to the profit of thy Maſter, and pleaſure of thy Miſtriſs.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: What Wine drink ye, Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.p: What Wine relliſhes your p • llate, good Mr. P • ttifog?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Nay, ask the woman.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Ellegant for her, I know her Di • t.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Believe me, I •• n her thank for't, I am of her ſide.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Marry, and reaſon, ſir, we have entertain'd you for our Atorney.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: A Cup of neat Allegant?

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Yes, but do not make it ſpeak Welch, boy.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: How mean you?

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Put no Me ••• glin in't, ye rogue.
sp.stage:
They ſit down, Pettifog pulls ou •
•• p • rs.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Not a drop, as I am crue Britain.
sp.stage: Enter Franckford, Euſtace, Luce, and Mr. Dodge a Lawyer to another Table, and a Drawer.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: Show a private room, Drawer.

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: Welcome Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Euſt.
sp.p: As far as you can from noiſe, boy.

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: Further this way then, ſir; for in the next room there are three or four Fiſh-wives taking up a brabling buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: Let's not ſit near them by any means.

sp.speaker: Dodge.
sp.p: Fill Canary, ſirrah.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: And what do you think of my Cauſe, Mr. Dodge?

sp.speaker: Dodge.
sp.p: Oh we ſhall carry it moſt indubitably: you have money to go through with the buſineſs, and ne'ro fear it but we'l trownce 'em, you are the true Father.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: The mother will confeſs as much.

sp.speaker: Dodge.
sp.p: Yes Miſtriſs, we have taken her Affidavit. Look you ſir, here's the Anſwer to his Declaration.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: You may think ſtrange, ſir, that I am at charge to call a Charge upon me: but 'tis truth, I made a Purch • ſe lately, and in that I did eſtate the Childe, 'bout which I'm ſued, Joynt-purchaſer in all the Land I bought: now that's one reaſon that I ſhould have care, beſides the • ye of blood, to keep the Childe under my wing, and ſee it carefully inſtructed in thoſe fair Abilities may make it worthy hereafter to be mine, and enjoy the Land I have provided for't.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: Right, and I councel'd you to make that Purchaſe; and therefore Ile not have the Childe brought up by ſuch a Coxcomb as now ſues for him, he'd bring him up onely to be a Swa • ber: he was born a Merchant and a Gentleman, and he ſhall live and die ſo.

sp.speaker: Dodge.
sp.p: Worthy Miſtriſs, I drink to you: you are a good woman, and but few of ſo noble a patience.
Score a quart of Allegant t'oth' Woodcock.

sp.speaker: 1 Boy.
sp.p: Will you have any muſick, Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Muſick amongſt Lawyers? here's nothing but diſcord. What, Rafe! here's another of my young Cuckoes I heard laſt April, before I heard the Nightingale: no muſick, good Rafe: here boy, your father was a Taylor, and methinks by your leering eye you ſhould take after him. A good boy, make a leg handſomly, ſcrape your ſelf out of our company. And what do you think of my Suit, ſir?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Why, look you, ſir: The Defendant was arreſted firſt by Latitate in an Action of Treſpaſs.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: And a Lawyer told me it ſhould have been an Action of the Caſe, ſhould it not wife?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: I have no skill in Law, ſir: but you heard a Lawyer ſay ſo.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: I, but your Action of the Caſe is in that point too tickliſh.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: But what do you think, ſhall I overthrow my adverſary?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Sans queſtion: The childe is none of yours: what of that? I marry a widow is poſſeſt of a Ward, ſhall not I have the tuition of that Ward? Now ſir, you lye at a ſtronger Ward; for partus ſequitur ventrem, ſays the Civil Law: and if you were within compaſs of the four Seas, as the common Law goes, the childe ſhall be yours certain.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: There's ſome comfort in that yet. Oh your Atorneys in Guild-hall have a fine time on't.

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.p: You are in effect both Judge and Jury your ſelves.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: And how you will laugh at your Clients when you ſit in a Tavern, and call them Coxcombs, and whip up a Cauſe, as a Barber trims his Cuſtomers on a Chriſtmaſs Eve, a ſnip, a wipe, and away.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: That's ordinary, ſir: you ſhall have the like at a Niſi Prius. Oh you are welcome, Sir.

sp.speaker: 1 Client.
sp.p: Sir, you'l be mindful of my Suit.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: As I am religious, Ile drink to you.

sp.speaker: 1 Client.
sp.p: I thank you. By your favor, Miſtriſs. I have much buſineſs and cannot ſtay; but there's money for a quart of Wine.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: By no means.

sp.speaker: 1 Client.
sp.p: I have ſaid, Sir.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: He's my Client ſir, and he muſt pay; this is my tribute. Cuſtom is not more truly paid in the Sound of Denmark.

sp.speaker: 2 Client.
sp.p: Good ſir, be careful of my buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Your Declaration's drawn, ſir: Ile drink to you.

sp.speaker: 2 Client.
sp.p: I cannot drink this morning; but there's money for a pottle of Wine.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Oh good ſir.

sp.speaker: 2 Client.
sp.p: I have done, ſir. Morrow, Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: We ſhall drink good cheap, Mr. Pettifog.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: And we ſate here long you'd ſay ſo. I have ſare here in this Tavern but one half hour, drunk but three pin •• of wine, and what with the offering of my Clients in that ſhort time, I have got nine ſhillings clear, and paid all the Reckoning.

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.p: Almoſt a Councellors Fee.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: And a great one as the world goes in Guild-hall; for now our young Clerks ſhare with 'em, to help 'em to Clients.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: I don't think but that the Cucking-ſtool is an enemy to a number of brables, that would elſe be determined by Law.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: 'Tis ſo indeed, ſir: My Client that came in now, ſues his neighbor for kicking his Dog, and uſing the defamatory ſpeeches, Come out Cuckolds curr.

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.p: And what ſhall you recover upon this ſpeech?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: In Guild-hall I aſſure you, the other that came in was an Informer, a precious knaye.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Will not the Ballad of Flood that was preſt, make them leave their knavery?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Ile tell you how he was ſerved: This Informer comes into Turnball-ſtreet to a Victualling-houſe, and there falls in league with a Wench.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: A Tweak, or Bronſtrops, I learnt that name in a Play.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Had belike ſome private dealings with her, and there got a Gooſe.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: I would he had got two, I cannot away with an Informer

sp.speaker: Pet.
Comp.
sp.p: Marry, I th • nk her with all my heart for't.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: Here's a Gen • leman, one Juſtice Woodroff enquires for Mr. Franckford. Fr. Oh, my brother and the other Compremiſer come to take up the buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: We have conferred and labored for your peace, unleſs your ſtubborneſs prohibit it; and be aſſured, as we can determine it, the Law will end, for we have ſought the Caſes.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: If the Childe fall to my ſhare, I am content to end upon any conditions, the Law ſhall run on head-long elſe.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: Your purſe muſt run by like a Foot-man then.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: 〈◊〉 purſe ſhall run open mouth'd at thee.

sp.speaker: Coun.
sp.p: My friend, be calm, you ſhall hear the reaſons: I have ſtood up for you, pleaded your Cauſe, but am overthrown, yet no fur • her yielded than your own pleaſure; you may go on in Law if you refuſe our Cenſure.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: I will yield to nothing but my Childe.

sp.speaker: Coun.
sp.p: 'Tis then as vain in us to ſeek your peace, yet take the reaſons with you: This Gentleman firſt ſpeaks, a Juſtice to me, and obſerve it, A childe that's baſe and illegitimate born, the father found, who (if the need require it) ſecures the charge and dammage of the Pariſh but the father? who charged with education but the father? then by clear conſequence he ought for what he pays for, to enjoy. Come to the ſtrength of reaſon, upon which the Law is grounded: the earth brings forth, this ground or that, her Crop of Wheat or Rye, whether ſhall the Seeds-man enjoy the ſheaf, or leave it to the earth that brought it forth? The ſummer tree brings forth her natural fruit, ſpreads her large arms, who but the lord of it ſhall pluck Apples, or command the lops? or ſhall they ſink into the root agen? 'tis ſtill moſt cleer upon the Fathers part.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p:
All this Law I deny, and will be mine own Lawyer. Is not the earth our Mother? And ſhall not the earth have all her children agen?
