I would ſee that Law durſt keep any of us back, ſhe'l have Lawyers and all firſt, tho they be none of her beſt children. My wife is the mother, and ſo much for the Civil-law. Now I come agen, and y' are gone at the Common-law: ſuppoſe this is my ground, I keep a Sow upon it, as it might be my wife,
you keep a Boar, as it might be my adverſary here; your 〈◊〉 comes fo • ming into my ground, jumbles with my Sow, and •• llowes in her mire, my Sow cryes week▪ as if ſhe had Pigs in her belly, who ſhall keep theſe Pigs? he the Boar, or ſhe the Sow?

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Paſt other alteration, I am changed, the Law is on the Mothers part.

sp.speaker: Coun.
sp.p: For me, I am ſtrong in your opi ••• n, I never knew my judgement erre ſo far, I was confirmed upon the other part, and now am flat againſt it.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Sir you muſt yeild, believe it there's no Law can relieve you.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: I found it in my ſelf: well ſir, the childe 's your wifes, Ile ſtrive no further in it, and being ſo neer unto agreement, let us go quite th • ough to't; forgive my fault, and I forgive my charges, nor will I take back the inherit • nce I made unto it.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Nay, there you ſhall finde me kinde too, I have a pottle of Claret, and a Capon to ſupper for you; but no more Mutton for you, not a bit.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.p: Yes a ſhoulder, and we'l be there too, or a leg opened with Veniſon ſawce.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: No legs opened by your leave; not no ſuch fawce.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Well brother, and neighbor, I am glad you are friends.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: All, all joy at it.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Urſe, come kiſs Urſe, all friends.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.p: Stay ſir, one thing I would adviſe you, 'tis Councel worth; Fee, tho I be no Lawyer, 'tis Phyſick indeed, & cu • es Cuckoldry, to keep that • ightful brand out of your forehead, that it ſhall not dare to meet or look out at any window to you, 'tis better then an Onion to a green wound i'th left hand made by fire, it takes out ſcar and all.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: This were a rare receipt, Ile content you for your skill.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.p: Make here a flat divorce between your ſelves, be you no huſband, not let her be no wife, within two hours you may ſ • lute agen, wooe, and wed afreſh, and then the Cuckold's blotted. This medicine is approved.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p:
Excellent, and I thank you: Urſe, I renounce thee, and I renounce my ſelf from thee; thou art a Widow, Urſe, I will go hang my ſelf two hours, and ſo long thou ſhalt drown thy ſelf, then will we meet agen in the Peaſe-field by Biſhops-Hall, and as the Swads and the Cods ſhall inſtruct us, we'l talk of a new
matter.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: I will be ruled, fare you well ſir.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Farewel widdow, remember time and place, change your Clothes too, do ye hear, widow? Sir, I am beholding to your good Councel.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.p: But you'l not follow your own ſo far I hope? you ſaid you'd hang your ſelf.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: No I have deviſed a better way, I will go drink my ſelf dead for an hour, then when I awake • gen, I am a freſh new man, and ſo I go a wo • ing.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.p: That's handſome, and Ile lend thee a dagger.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: For the long Weapon let me alone then.

sp.speaker: Clare.
sp.p: Oh ſir, are you return'd? I do expect to hear ſtrange news now.

sp.speaker: Leſſ.
sp.p: I have none to tell you, I am onely to relate I have done ill at a womans bidding, that's I hope no news: yet wherefore do I call that ill, begers my abſolute happineſs? you now are mine, I muſt enjoy you ſolely.

sp.speaker: Clare.
sp.p: By what warrant?

sp.speaker: Leſſ.
sp.p: By your own condition, I have been at Callis, performed your will, drawn my revengful ſword, and ſlain my neereſt and beſt friend i'th world I had, for your ſake.

sp.speaker: Clare.
sp.p: Slain your friend for my ſake?

sp.speaker: Leſſ.
sp.p: A moſt ſad truth.

sp.speaker: Clare.
sp.p: And your beſt friend?

sp.speaker: Leſſ.
sp.p: My chiefeſt.

sp.speaker: Clare.
sp.p: Then of all men you are moſt miſerable, nor have you ought further'd your ſuit in this, though I enjoyn'd you to't, for I had thought that I had been the beſt eſteemed friend you had i'th world.

sp.speaker: Leſſ.
sp.p: Ye did not wiſh I hope, that I ſhould have murder'd you?

sp.speaker: Clare.
sp.p: You ſhall perceive more of that hereafter: But I pray fit tell me, for I do freeze with expectation of it, it chills my heart with horror till I know what friends blood you have ſacrificed to your fury and to my fatal ſport, this bloody Riddle? who is it you have ſlain?

sp.speaker: Leſſ.
sp.p: Bonvile the Bridegroom.

sp.speaker: Clare.
sp.p: Say? Oh you have ſtruck him dead thorough my heart, in being true to me, you have proved in this the falſeſt Traitor: oh I am loſt for ever: yet wherefore am I loſt? rather recovered from a deadly witchcraft, and upon his grave I will not gather Rue, but Violets to bleſs my wedding ſtrewings; good ſir tell'me, are you certain he is dead?

sp.speaker: Leſſ.
sp.p: Never, never to be recovered.

sp.speaker: Clare.
sp.p: Why now ſir, I do love you, with an entire heart, I could dance methinks, never did wine or mu •• ch ſtir in woman, a ſweerer touch of Mirth, I will marry you, inſtantly r • arry you.

sp.speaker: Leſſ.
sp.p: This woman has ſtrange changes, you are takne ſtrangely with his death.

sp.speaker: Clare.
sp.p: Ile give the reaſon I have to be thus extaſied with joy: know 〈◊〉 , that you have ſlain my deereſt friend, and faraleſt enemy.

sp.speaker: Leſſ.
sp.p: Moſt ſtrange!

sp.speaker: Clare.
sp.p:
'Tis true, you have ta'ne a maſs of Lead from off my heart, for ever would have ſunk it in deſpair; when you beheld me yeſterday, I ſtood as if a Merchant walking on the Downs, ſhould ſee ſome goodly Veſſel of his own ſunk 'fore his face i'th Harbor, and my heart retained no more heat then a man that toyles, and vain'y labors to put out the flames that burns his houſe to'th bottom. I will tell you a ſtrange concealement, ſir, and till this minute never revealed, and I will tell it now, ſmiling and not bluſhing; I did love that Bonvyle, (not as I ought, but as a woman might that's beyond reaſon,) I did do • t upon him, tho he near knew of't, and beholding him before my face wedded unto another, and all my intereſt in him forfeited, I fell into deſpair, 〈◊〉 that inſtant you urging your Suit to me, and I thinki ••
〈◊〉 I had been your onely friend i'th world, I heartily did wiſh you would have kill'd that friend your ſelf, to have ended all my ſorrow, and had prepared it, that unwittingly you ſhould have don't by poiſon.

sp.speaker: Leſſ.
sp.p: Strange amazement!

sp.speaker: Clare.
sp.p: The effects of a ſtrange Love.

sp.speaker: Leſſ.
sp.p: 'Tis a dream ſure.

sp.speaker: Clare.
sp.p: No 'tis real ſir, believe it.

sp.speaker: Leſſ.
sp.p: Would it were not.

sp.speaker: Clare.
sp.p: • hat ſir, you have done bravely, 'tis your Miſtriſs that tells you, you have done ſo.

sp.speaker: Leſſ.
sp.l: But my Conſcience▪
Is of Councel 'gainſt you, and pleads otherwiſe:
Vertue in her paſt actions glories ſtill,
But vice throwes loathed looks on former ill.
But did you love this Bonvile?

sp.speaker: Clare.
sp.p: Strangely ſir, almoſt to a degree of madneſs.

sp.speaker: Leſſ.
sp.p:
Truſt a woman? never henceforward, I will rather truſt the winds which Lapland Witches ſell to men, all that they have is feign'd, their teeth, their hair, their bluſhes, nay their conſcience
too is feigned, let 'em paint, load themſelves with Clo • h of Tiſſue, they cannot yet hide woman, that will appear and diſgrace all. The neceſſity of my fate! certain this woman has bewitched me here, for I cannot chuſe but love her. Oh how faral this might have proved, I would it had for me, it would not grieve me, tho my ſword had ſplit his heart in ſunder, I had then deſtroyed o • e that may prove my Rival; oh but then what had my horror bin, my guilt of conſcience? I know ſome do ill at womens bidding i'th Dog-days, and repent all the Winter after: no, I account it treble happineſs that Bonvile lives, but 'tis my chiefeſt glory that our friendſhip is divided.

sp.speaker: Clare.
sp.p: Noble friend, why do you talk to your ſelf?

sp.speaker: Leſſ.
sp.p: Should you do ſo, you'd talk to an ill woman, fare you well, for ever fare you well; I will do ſomewhat to make as fatal breach and difference in Bonviles love as mine, I am fixt in't, my melancholly and the devil ſhall faſhion't.

sp.speaker: Clare.
sp.p: You will not leave me thus?

sp.speaker: Leſſ.
sp.p: Leave you for ever, and may my friends blood whom you loved ſo deerly, for ever lye impoſtumed in your breaſt, and i'th end choak you. Womans cruelty
This black and fatal thread hath ever ſpun,
It muſt undo, or elſe it is undone.

sp.speaker: Clare.
sp.p:
I am every way loſt, and no meanes to 〈◊〉
•• e, but bleſt repentance: what two unvalued Jewels am I at once deprived of? now I ſuffer deſervedly, there's no proſperity ſettled, Fortune plays ever with our good or ill,
Like Croſs and Pile, and turns up which ſhe will.
Friend?

sp.speaker: Clare.
sp.p:
Oh you are the welcomeſt under heaven:
• eſſingham did but fright me, yet I fear that you are hurt to danger.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: Not a ſcratch.

sp.speaker: Clare.
sp.p: Indeed you look exceeding well, methinks.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: I have bin Sea-ſick lately, and we count that excellent Phyſick. How does my Annabel •

sp.speaker: Clare.
sp.p: As well ſir, as the fear of ſuch a loſs as your eſteemed ſelf, will ſuffer her.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: Have you ſeen Leſſingham ſince he returned?

sp.speaker: Clare.
sp.p: He departed hence but now, and left with me a report had almoſt kill'd me.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: What was that?

sp.speaker: Clare.
sp.p: That he had kill'd you.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: So he has.

sp.speaker: Clare.
sp.p: You mock me.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: He has kill'd me for a friend, for ever ſilenc't all 〈◊〉 between us; you may now go and embrace him, for he has fulfilled the purpoſe of that Letter.

sp.speaker: Clare.
sp.p: Oh I know't.
And had you known this which I meant to have ſent you an hour 'fore you mere married to your wife, the Riddle had been conſtr • ed.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: Strange! this expreſſes that you did love me.

sp.speaker: Clare.
sp.p: With a violent affection.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: Violent indeed; for it ſeems it was your purpoſe to have ended it in violence on your friend: the unfortunate Leſſingham unwittingly ſhould have been the Executioner.

sp.speaker: Clare.
sp.p: 'Tis true.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: And do you love me ſtill?

sp.speaker: Clare.
sp.p: I may eaſily confeſs it, ſince my extremity is ſuch that I muſt needs ſpeak or die,

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: And you would enjoy me though I am married?

sp.speaker: Clare.
sp.p: No indeed not I ſir: you are to ſleep with a ſweet Bed-fellow would knit the brow at that.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: Come, come, a womans telling truth makes amends for her playing falſe. You would en • oy me▪

sp.speaker: Clare.
sp.p: If you were a Batchelor or Widower,
Afore all the great Ones living.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: But 'tis impoſſible to give you preſent ſatisfaction, for my Wife is young and heal • hful; and I like the ſummer and the harveſt of our Love, which yet I have not taſted of, ſo well, that and you'l credit me, for me her days ſhall ne're be ſhortned: let your reaſon therefore turn you another way, and call to minde with beſt obſervance, the accompliſht graces of that brave Gentleman whom late you ſent to his deſtruction: A man ſo every way deſerving, no one action of his in all his life time e're degraded him from the honor he was born too; think 〈◊〉 obſervant he'l prove to you in nobler requeſt, that ſo obeyed you in a bad one:
sp.l: And remember that afore you engaged him to an act
Of horror, to the killing of his friend,
He bore his ſteerage true in every part,
Led by the Compaſs of a noble heart.

sp.speaker: Clare.
sp.p:
Why do you praiſe him thus? You ſaid but now he was utterly loſt to you▪ now 't appears you are friends, elſe you 'd
not deliver of him ſuch a worthy commendation.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: You miſtake, utterly miſtake that I am friends with him, in ſpeaking this good of him: To what purpoſe do I praiſe him? onely to this fatal end, that you might fall in love and league with him. And what worſe office can I do i'th world unto my enemy, than to endeavor by all means poſſible to marry him unto a Whore? and there I think ſhe ſtands.

sp.speaker: Clare.
sp.p: Is Whore a name to be beloved? If not, what reaſon have I ever to love that man puts it upon me falſely? You have wrought a ſtrange alteration in me: were I a man, I would drive you with my ſword into the field, and there put my wrong to ſilence. Go, y'are not worthy to be a womans friend in the leaſt part that concerns honorable reputation; for you are a Liar.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: I will love you now with a noble obſervance, if you will continue this hate unto me: gather all thoſe graces from whence you have faln yonder, where you have left 'em in Leſſingham, he that muſt be your husband; And though henceforth I ceaſe to be his friend, I will appear his nobleſt enemy, and work reconcilement 'tween you.

sp.speaker: Clare.
sp.p: No, you ſhall not, you ſhall not marry him to a Strumpet; for that word I ſhall ever hate you.

sp.speaker: Leſſ.
sp.l: And for that one deed,
I ſhall ever love you. Come, convert your thoughts
To him that beſt deſerves 'em, Leſſingham.
It's moſt certain you have done him wrong,
But your repentance and compaſſion now
May make amends: diſperſe this melancholly,
And on that turn of Fortunes Wheel depend,
When all Calamities will mend, or end.
sp.stage: Enter Compaſs, Raymond, Euſtaco, Lyonel, Grover.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.l: Gentlemen, as you have been witneſs to our Divorce,
You ſhall now be ••• dence to our next meeting,
Which I look for every minute, if you pleaſe Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.p: We came for the ſame purpoſe, man.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.l: I do think you'l ſee me come off with as ſmooth
A forehead, make my Wife as honeſt a woman once more,
As a man ſometimes would deſire, I mean of her 〈◊〉 ,
And a teeming woman as ſhe has been. Nay ſurely I
Do think to make the Childe as lawful a childe too,
As a couple of unmarried people can beget; and let
It be begotten when the father is beyond Sea, as this
Was: do but note.

sp.speaker: Euſt.
sp.p: 'Tis that we 〈◊〉 for.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: You have wai •• d the good hour: ſee, ſhe comes, a little room I beſeech you, ſilence and obſervation.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.p: All your own, ſir.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Good morrow fair Maid.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Miſtaken in both ſir, neither fair, nor Maid.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: No? a married woman.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: That's it I was ſir, a poor widdow now.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: A widdow? Nay then I muſt make a little bold with you, ' 〈◊〉 a kin to mine own caſe, I am a wiveleſs husband too, how long have you been a widow pray? nay, do not weep.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: I cannot chuſe to think the loſs I had.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: He was an honeſt man to thee it ſeems.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Honeſt quoth, a, oh.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: By my feek, and thoſe are great loſſes, an honeſt man is not to be found in every hole, nor every ſtreet, if I took a whole pariſh in ſometimes I might ſay true, for ſtincking Mackarel may be cried for new.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.p: Some what ſententious.

sp.speaker: Euſt.
sp.p: Oh, ſilence was an Article enjoyned.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: And how long is it ſince you loſt your honeſt husband?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Oh the memory is too freſh, and your ſight makes my ſorrow double.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: My ſight? why was he like me?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Your left hand to your right, is not more like.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Nay then I cannot blame thee to weep, an honeſt man I warrant him, and thou hadſt a great loſs of him; ſuch a proportion, ſo limb'd, ſo coloured, ſo fed.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.p: Yes faith, and ſo taught too.

sp.speaker: Euſt.
sp.p: Nay, will you break the Law?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Twins were never liker.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Well, I love him the better, whatſoever is become of him, and how many children did he leave thee at his departure?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Onely one ſir.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: A Boy, or a Girl?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: A Boy, Sir.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p:
Juſt • i • e one eaſe ſtill • my wife, reſt • er ſoul, left • e a
Boy too, a chopping Boy I warrant.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Yes if you call 'em ſo.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: I, mine is a chopping Boy, I mean to make either a Cook or a Butcher of him for thoſe are your chopping Boys. And what profeſſion was your husband of▪

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: He went to Sea, ſir, and there 〈◊〉 his living.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Mine own faculty too, and you can like a man of that p • ofeſſion well?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: For his ſweet ſake whom I ſo deerly loved, more dee • ly loſt, I muſt think well of it.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Muſt you? I do think then thou muſt venter to Sea once agen, if thou • 't be rul'd by me.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Oh Sir, but there's one thing more burdenſome to us, then moſt of others wives, which moves me a little to d • ſtaſte it, long time we endure the 〈◊〉 of our husbands, ſometimes many years, and then if any ſlip in woman be, as long vacations may make Lawyers hungry, and Tradeſmen cheaper penny-worths afford, (then otherwiſe they would for ready coin) ſcandals fly out, and we poor ſouls branded with want on living, and incontinency, when alas (conſider) can we do withal?

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: They are fools, and not ſay 〈◊〉 that do not conſider that, I'm ſure your husband was not of that minde, if he were like me.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: No indeed, he would bear kinde and honeſtly.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.l: He was the wiſer, alack your land and freſh-water men
Never underſtand what wonders are done at Sea; yet
They may obſerve a ſhore, that a Hen having taſted
The Cock, kill him, and ſhe ſhall lay Eggs afterwards.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: That's very true indeed.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: And ſo may women, why not? may not a man get two or three children at once? One muſt be born before another, you know.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Even this diſcretion my ſweet husband had: You more and more reſemble him.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.l: Then if they knew what things are done at ſea, where
The Winds themſelves do copulate, and bring forth iſſue,
As thus: In the old wo • ld there were▪ but • our in all,
As Nor, Eaſt, Sou, and Weſt theſe dwelt far from •• e another,
Yet by meeting they have ingendred Nor-Eaſt, Sou-Eaſt,
Sou-Weſt, Nor-Weſt, then they were eight▪ Of them▪
Were begotten Nor-Nor-Eaſt, Nor-Nor-Weſt, Sou-Sou-Eaſt,
Sou-Sou-Weſt, and thoſe two So vs were Sou-Eaſt and Sou▪Weſt
Daughters, and indeed there is a family now of 32 of 'em,
That they have fill'd every corner of the wo • ld, and yet for
All this, you ſee theſe baudy Bellows-menders when they
Come aſho • e, will be offering to take up Womens coats
In the ſtreet.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Still my husbands diſcretion!

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: So I ſay, if your Land-men did underſtand that we ſend Windes from Sea, to do our commendations to our wives, they would not blame you as they do.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: We cannot help it.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.l: But you ſhall help it. Can you love me, widow?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: If I durſt confeſs what I do think, ſir,
I know what I would ſay.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Durſt confeſs? Why whom do you fear? here's none but honeſt Gentlemen my friends; let them hear, and Never bluſh for't.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: I ſhall be thought too weak to yeild at firſt.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: Tuſh, that's niceneſs; come, we heard all the reſt,
The firſt true ſtroke of love ſinks thee deepeſt,
If you love him, ſay ſo.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.l: I have a Boy of mine own, I tell you that afore hand,
You ſhall not need to fear me that way.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Then I do love him.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.l: So here will be man and wife to morrow then, what though
We meet ſtrangers, we may love one another
Ne'r the worſe for that. Gentlemen, I invite
You all to my Wedding.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: We'l all attend it.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.l: Did not I tell you, I would fetch it off fair, let any
Man lay a Cuckold to my charge, if he dares now.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.p: 'Tis ſlander who ever does it.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.l: Nay, it will come to P •• ty Laſſery at leaſt, and without
Compaſs of the general pardon too, or I'le bring him to a
Foul ſheet, if he has ne're a clean one, or let me
Hear him that will ſay I am not father to the childe I begot.

sp.speaker: Euſt.
sp.p: None will adventure any of thoſe.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Or that my wife that ſhall be, is not as honeſt a woman, as ſome other mens wives are?

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.p: No queſtion of that.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: How fine and ſleek my brows are now?

sp.speaker: Euſt.
sp.p: I when you are married, they I come to themſelves agen.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.l: You may call me Bridegroom if you pleaſe now,
For the Gueſts are bidden.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Good Maſter Bridegroom.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.l: Come Widow then, ere the next Ebb and Tide,
If I be Bridegroom, thou ſhalt be the Bride.

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.p: BElieve me, I was never more ambitious, or covetous, if I may call it ſo, of any fortune greater than this one, but to behold his face.

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.l: And now's the time; for from a much feared danger as
I heard, he's late come over.

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.p: And not ſeen you yet? 'tis ſome unkindneſs.

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.p: You may think it ſo; but for my part, ſir, I account it none: what know I but ſome buſineſs of import and weighty conſequence, more near to him then any formal Complement to me, may for a time detain him: I preſume no jealouſie can be aſperſt on him, for which he cannor well •• ology.

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.l: You are a Creature every way compleat,
As good a Wife, as Woman; ſo whoſe ſake
As I in duty am endeer'd to you,
So ſhall I owe him ſervice.

sp.speaker: Leſſ.
sp.p: The ways to Love, and Crowns, lye both through blood, for in 'em both all Lets muſt be removed, it could be ſtiled no true ambition elſe. I am grown big with pro • ect: Project, ſaid I? Rather with ſudden miſchief; which without
sp.l: A ſpeedy birth fills me with painful throwes,
And I am now in labor. Th ••• s occaſion
That giveſt me a fit ground to work upon,
It ſhould be Rochfield, one ſince our departure
It ſeems ingrafted in this Family:
Indeed the Houſes Minion, ſince from the Lord
To the loweſt Groom, all with unite conſent
Speak him ſo largely. Nor as it appears
By this their private Conference, is he grown
Leaſt in the Brides •• inion. A foundation
On which I will erect •• rave Revenge.

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.l: Sir,-What kinde Offices lyes in your way
To do for him, I ſhall be thankful for,
And reckon them mine own.

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.p: In acknowledgement I kiſs your hand, ſo with a gratitude never to be forgot, I take my leave.

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.l: I mine of you, with hourly expectation
Of a long-lookt for husband.

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.p: May it thrive according to your wiſhes.

sp.speaker: Leſſ.
sp.p: Now's my turn. Without offence, Sir, may I beg your name?

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.p: 'Tis that I never yet denied to any, nor will to you that ſeem a Gentleman: 'tis Rochfield.

sp.speaker: Leſſ.
sp.p: Rochfield? You are then the man whoſe nobleneſs, vertue, valor, and good parts, have voice'd you loud. Dover and Sandwich, Marget, and all the Coaſt is full of you: but more, as an Eye-witneſs of all theſe, and with moſt truth, the Maſter of this houſe hath given them large expreſſions.

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.p: Therein his love exceeded much my merit.

sp.speaker: Leſſ.
sp.l: That's your modeſty:
Now I as one that goodneſs love in all men,
And honoring that which is but found in few,
Deſire to know you better.

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.p: Pray your name?

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.p: A friend to Mr. Bonvile?

sp.speaker: Leſſ.
sp.p: In the number of thoſe which he eſteems moſt dear to him, he reckons me not laſt.

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.p: So I have heard.

sp.speaker: Leſſ.
sp.l: Sir, you have cauſe • oble • s the lucky Planer

Beneath which you were 〈◊〉
• was a bright ſtar
And then ſhined cle •• upon you for as you
Are every way well par • ed, ſo I • old you.
In all deſigns mark't to be fortunate.

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.l: Pray do 〈◊〉 ſtr ••• h your love to flattery,
'T may call it then in queſtion; grow I pray you
To ſome particulars.

sp.speaker: Leſſ.
sp.l: I have obſerved but late your parting with the Virgin
Bride, and therein ſome affection

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Leſſ.
sp.p: With pardon, in this I ſtill app ••• d your happineſs, and praiſe the bleſſed influence of your ſtars: for how can it be poſſible that ſhe, unkindly left upon the B • ide-day, and diſappointed of thoſe Nuptial ſweets that night expected, but ſhould take the occaſion ſo fairly offered? Nay, and ſtand excuſed aſwell in deteſtation of a ſcorn, ſcarce in a husband heard of, as ſelecting a Gentleman in all things ſo compleat, to do her thoſe neglected offices, her youth and beauty juſtly challengeth.

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.l: Some plot to wrong the Bride, and I now
Will marry Craft with Cunning, if he'l bite,
Ile give him line to play on: wer't your caſe
You being young as I am, would you intermit
So fair and ſweet occaſion?

sp.speaker: Leſſ.
sp.l: Yet miſ-conceive me not, I do intreat you;
To think I can be of that eaſie wit,
Or of that malice to defame a Lady,
Were ſhe ſo kinde ſo to expoſe her ſelf,
Nor is ſhe ſuch a creature.

sp.speaker: Leſſ.
sp.l: On this foundation I can build higher ſtill, (ſir I beleiv't)
I hear you two call Couſins; comes your kindred
By the Woodreffs, o • the Bonviles?

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.l: From neither, 'tis a word of courteſie
Late interchanged betwixt us, otherwiſe
We are forreign as two ſtrangers.

sp.speaker: Leſſ.
sp.p: Better ſtill.

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.l: I would not have you grow too inward with me
Upon ſo ſmall a knowledge; yet to ſatisfie you,
And in ſome kinde too to delight my ſelf,
Thoſe Bracelets and the Carckanet ſhe wears,
She gave me once.

sp.speaker: Leſſ.
sp.p: They were the firſt, and ſpecial Tokens paſt betwixt her and her husband.

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.p: 'Tis confeſt: what I have ſaid, I have ſaid: Sir, you have power perhaps to wrong m •• or to in • re her; this you may do, but as you are a Gentleman I hope you will do neither.

sp.speaker: Leſſ.
sp.l: 'Truſt upon't.
If I drown Ile ſink ſome along withme;
For of all miſeries I hold that chief,
Wretched to be, when none co-pa •• s our grief.
Here's another Anvile to work on: I muſt now
Make this my Maſter-piece; for your old Foxes
Are ſeldom ta'ne in Springes.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.l: What, my Friend!
You are happily returned; and yet I 〈◊〉
Somewhat to make it perfect. Where's your Friend,
My Son in Law?

sp.speaker: Leſſ.
sp.p: Oh ſir!

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: I pray ſir reſolve me; for I do ſuffer ſtrangely till I know if he be in ſafety.

sp.speaker: Leſſ.
sp.l: Fare you well: 'Tis not fit
I ſhould relate his danger.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: I muſt know't. I have a Quarrel to you already, for enticing my Son in Law to go over: Tell me quickly, or I ſhall make it grea • er.

sp.speaker: Leſſ.
sp.p: Then truth is, he's dangerouſly wounded.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: But he's not dead I hope?

sp.speaker: Leſſ.
sp.p: No ſir, not dead; yet ſure your daughter may take liberty to chuſe another.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Why that gives him dead.

sp.speaker: Leſſ.
sp.l: Upon my life Sir, no; your ſon's in health
As well as I am.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Strange! you deliver Riddles.

sp.speaker: Leſſ.
sp.l: I told you he was wounded, and 'tis true,
He is wounded in his Reputation.
I told you likewiſe, which I am lo • h to repeat,
That your fair-Daughter might take liberty
To embrace another. That's the conſequence
That makes my beſt Friend wounded in his Fame.
This is all I can deliver.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.l: I muſt have more of't;
For I do ſweat already, and Ile ſweat more;
'Tis good they ſay to c •• e Aches, and o'th ſudden
I am ſore from head to foot, let me taſte the worſt.

sp.speaker: Leſſ.
sp.l: Know Sir, if ever there 〈◊〉 truth in falſhood,
Then 'tis moſt true, your Daug •••• plays moſt falſe
With Bonvile, and hath choſe for her Favorite
The man that now paſt by me, Rochfield.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.l: Say? I would thou hadſt ſpoke this on Callis-ſands,
And I within my Sword and Ponyards length
Of that falſe throat of thine. I pray ſir, tell me
Of what Kin or Alliance do you take me
To the Gentlewoman you late mentioned?

sp.speaker: Leſſ.
sp.l: You are her Father.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.l: Why then of all men living, do you addreſs
This Report to me, that ought of all men b •• thing
To have been the laft o'th Rowl, except the husband,
That ſhould have heard of't?

sp.speaker: Leſſ.
sp.l: For her honor Sir, and yours;
That your good Councel may rec • aim her.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.l: I thank you.

sp.speaker: Leſſ.
sp.l: She has departed ſir, upon my knowledge,
With Jewels, and with Bracelets, the firſt Pledges,
And confirmation of th'unhappy Contract
Between her ſelf and husband.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.l: To whom?

sp.speaker: Leſſ.
sp.l: To Rochfield.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.l: Be not abuſed: but now,
Even now I ſaw her wear e'm.

sp.speaker: Leſſ.
sp.l: Very likely; 'tis fit, hearing her husband is returned,
That ſhe ſhould re-deliver 'em.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.l: But pray ſir tell me,
How is it likely ſhe could part with 'em,
When they are lockt about her Neck and Wriſts,
And the Key with her husband?

sp.speaker: Leſſ.
sp.l: Oh ſir, that's but practiſe;
She has got a trick to uſe another Key
Beſides her husbands.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.l: Sirrah, you do lie;
And were I to pay down a hundred pounds
For every Lie given, as men pay Twelve pence,
And worthily, for Swearing, I would give thee
The Lie, nay though it were in the Court of Honor
So oft, till of the Thouſands I am worth,
I had not left a hundred. For is't likely
So brave a Gentleman as Rochfield is,
That did ſo much at Sea to ſave my life,
Should now on Land ſhorten my wretched days,
In ruining my Daughter? A rank Lie!
Have you ſpread this to any but my ſelf?

sp.speaker: Leſſ.
sp.l: I am no Intelligencer.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.l: Why then 'tis yet a ſecret?
And that it may reſt ſo, Draw; Ile take order
You ſhall prate of it no further.

sp.speaker: Leſſ.
sp.l: Oh, my Sword
Is enchanted, Sir, and will not out o'th Scabbard:
I will leave you, ſir; yet ſay not I give ground,
For 'tis your own you ſtand on.
Clare here with Bonvile? excellent! on this
I have more to work. This goes to Annabel,
And it may increaſe the Whirlwinde.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: How now, Sir? Come, I know this choler bred in you
For the Voyage which I took at his entreaty;
But I muſt reconcile you.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.l: On my credit
There's no ſuch matter. I will tell you Sir,
And I will tell it in laughter: The Cauſe of it
Is ſo poor, ſo ridiculous, ſo impoſſible
To be believed! Ha, 〈◊〉 he came even now
And told me that one Rochfield, now a Gueſt
(And moſt worthy Sir, to be ſo) in my Houſe,
Is grown exceedingly familiar with my Daughter.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: Ha?

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.l: Your wife, and that he has had favors from her.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: Favors?
Love-tokens I did call 'em in my youth;
Lures to which Gallants ſpread their wings, and ſtoop
In Ladies boſoms. Nay, he was ſo falſe
To Truth and all good Manners, that thoſe Jewels
You lockt about her Neck, he did proteſt
She had given to Rochfield? Ha! methinks o'th ſudden
You do change colour. Sir, I would not have you
Believe this in leaſt part: My Daughter's honeſt,
And my Gueſs is a noble Fellow: And for this
Slander deliver'd me by Leſſingham,
I would have cut his throat.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: As I your Daughters,
If I finde not the Jewels 'bout her.

sp.speaker: Clare.
sp.l: Are you returned
With the Italian Plague upon you, Jealouſie?

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.l: Suppoſe that Leſſingham ſhould love my Daughter,
And thereupon faſhion your going over,
As now your Jealouſie, the ſtronger way
So to divide you, there were a fine Crotcher!
Do you ſtagger ſtill? If you continue thus,
I vo v you are not worth a welcome home
Neither from her, nor me. See, here ſhe comes.

sp.speaker: Clare.
sp.l: I have brought you home a Jewel.

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.l: Wear it your ſelf;
For theſe I wear are Fetters, not Favors.

sp.speaker: Clare.
sp.l: I lookt for better welcome.

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.l: Noble ſir, I muſt wooe your better knowledge?

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: Oh dear ſir,
My Wife will beſpeak it for you.

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.l: Ha? your Wife.

sp.speaker: VVood.
sp.l: Bear with him, ſir, he's ſtrangely off o'th hinges.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: The Jewels are i'th right place; but the Jewel
Of her heart ſticks yonder. You are angry with me
For my going over.

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.l: Happily more angry for your coming over.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: I ſent you my Will from Dover?

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.l: Yes Sir.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: Fetch it.

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.l: I ſhall Sir, but leave your Self-will with you.

sp.speaker: VVood.
sp.l: This is fine, the woman will be mad too.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: Sir, I would ſpeak with you.

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.l: And I with you of all men living.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: I muſt have ſatisfaction from you.

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.l: Sir, it growes upon the time of payment.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.l: What's that? what's that? Ile have no whiſpering.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Look you, there's the Pattent
Of your deadly affection to me.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: 'Tis wellcome,
When I gave my ſelf for dead, I then made over
My Land unto you, now I finde your love
Dead to me, I will alter't.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Uſe your pleaſure,
A man may make a garment for the Moon,
Rather then fit your Conſtancy.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.l: How's this? Alter your Will.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: 'Tis in mine own diſpoſing,
Certainly I will alter't.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.l: Will you ſo my friend?
Why then I will alter mine too.
I had eſtated thee, thou peeviſh fellow,
In forty thouſand pounds after my death,
I can finde another Executor.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: Pray ſir, do,
Mine Ile alter without queſtion.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.l: Doeſt hear me?
And if I change not mine within this two hours,
May my Executors cozen all my kindred
To whom I bequeath Legacies.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: I am for a Lawyer, ſir.

sp.speaker: VVood.
sp.l: And I will be with one as ſoon as thy ſelf,
Though thou rideſt poſte to'th devil.

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.l: Stay let me follow, and cool him.

sp.speaker: VVood.
sp.l: Oh by no means,
You'l put a quarrel upon him for the wrong,
H'as done my Daughter.

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.l: No believe it ſir, he's my wiſht friend.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.l: Oh come, I know the way of't;
Carry it like a French quarrel, privately whiſper
Appoint to meet, and cut each others throats
With Cringes and Embraces, I proteſt
I will not ſuffer you exchange a word
Without I over hear't.

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.l: Uſe your pleaſure.

sp.speaker: Clare.
sp.l: You are like to make fine work now.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Nay, you are like to make a finer buiſſineſs of't.

sp.speaker: Clare.
sp.l: Come, come, I muſt ſowder you together.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: You? why I heard
A bird ſing lately, you are the onely cauſe
Works the diviſion.

sp.speaker: Clare.
sp.l: Who? As thou ever lovedſt me,
For I long, though I am a Maid, for't.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Leſſingham.

sp.speaker: Clare.
sp.l: Why then I do proteſt my ſelf firſt cauſe
Of the wrong, which he has put upon you both,
Which pleaſe you to walk in, I ſhall make good
In a ſhort relation; come Ile be the clew
To lead you forth this Labyrinth, this toyl
Of a ſuppoſed and cauſeleſs Jealouſie.
Cankers touch choiceſt fruit with their infection,
And Fevers ſeize thoſe of the beſt complexion.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.l: Sir, have I not ſaid I love you? if I have,
You may believ't before an Oracle,
For there's no trick in't, but the honeſt ſence.

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.l: Believe it, that I do, ſir.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.l: Your love muſt then
Be as plain with mine, that they may ſuit together:
I ſay you muſt not fight with my ſon Bonvile.

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.l: Not fight with him, ſir?

sp.speaker: VVood
sp.l: No, Not fight with him, ſir.
I grant you may be wronged, and I dare ſwear
So is my childe, but he is the husband, you know,
The womans lord, and muſt not always be told
Of his faults neither, I ſay you muſt not fight.

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.l: Ile ſwear it, if you pleaſe ſir.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.l: And forſwear I know't
E're you lay ope the ſecrets of your valour,
'Tis enough for me I ſaw you whiſper,
And I know what belongs to't.

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.l: To no ſuch end, aſſure you.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.l: I ſay you cannot fight with him.
If you be my friend, for I muſt uſe you,
Yonder's my foe, and you muſt be my Second,
Prepare the Slanderer, and get another
Better then thy ſelf too; for here's my Second,
One that will fetch him up, and fierk him too.
Get your tools, I know the way to Callis-ſands,
If that be your Fence-ſchool, hee'l ſhow you tricks 'faith,
Hee'l let blood your Calumny, your beſt guard
Will come to a Peccavi I believe.

sp.speaker: Leſſ.
sp.l: Sir, if that be your quarrel,
He's a party in it, and muſt maintain
The ſide with me, from him I collected
All thoſe Circumſtances concern your Daughter,
His own tongue's confeſſion.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.l: Who from him?
He will belie to do thee a pleaſure then,
If he ſpeak any ill upon himſelf,
I know he ne're could do an injury.

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.l: So pleaſe you, Ile relate it, ſir.

sp.speaker: VVood.
sp.l: Before her husband then, and here he is
In friendly poſture with my Daughter too;
I like that well. Son Bridegroom, and Lady Bride,
If you will hear a man defame himſelf,
(For ſo he muſt if he ſay any ill,) then liſten.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: Sir, I have heard this ſtory, and meet with your opinion in his goodneſs, the repitition will be needleſs.

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.p: Your father • as not, Sir. Ile be brief in the delivery.

sp.speaker: VVood.
sp.p: Do, do then, I long to hear it.

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.l: The firſt acquaintance I had with your Daughter,
Was on the Wedding-Eve.

sp.speaker: VVood.
sp.p: So, 'tis not ended yet, methinks.

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.p: I would have robb'd her.

sp.speaker: VVood.
sp.p: Ah, thief.

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.p: That Chain and Bracelet which ſhe wears upon her, ſhe ranſom'd with the full eſteem in Gold, which was with you my Venture.

sp.speaker: VVood.
sp.p: Ah, thief agen.

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.p: For any attempt againſt her honor, I vow I had no Thought on.

sp.speaker: VVood.
sp.p: An honeſt thief 'faith yet.

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.l: Which ſhe as nobly recompenc'd, brought me home,
And in her own diſcretion thought it meet,
For cover of my ſhame, to call me Couſin.

sp.speaker: VVood.
sp.l: Call a thief Couſin? Why, and ſo ſhe might,
For the Gold ſhe gave thee, ſhe ſtole from her husband,
'Twas all his now, yet 'twas a good Girl too.

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.p: The reſt you know, ſir.

sp.speaker: VVood.
sp.p: Which was worth all the reſt, thy valor Lad; but Ile have that in Print, becauſe I can no better utter it.

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.p: Thus (Jade unto my Wants, and ſpurred by my Neceſſities) I was going, but by that Ladies councel I was ſtaid; (for that Diſcourſe was our familiarity.) And this you may take for my Recantation, I am no more a thief.

sp.speaker: VVood.
sp.l: A bleſsing on thy heart,
And this was the firſt time I warrant thee too.

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.p: Your charitable Cenſure is not wrong'd in that.

sp.speaker: VVood.
sp.l: No, I knew 't could be but the firſt time at moſt;
But for thee (brave Valor) I have in ſtore,
That thou ſhalt need to be a thief no more.
Ha? What's this Muſick?

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: It chimes a Jopaean to your Wedding, ſir, if this be your Bride.

sp.speaker: Leſſ.
sp.p: Can you forgive me? ſome wilde diſtractions had overturned my own condition, and ſpilt the goodneſs you once knew in me, but I have carefully recovered it, and overthrown the fury on't.

sp.speaker: Clare.
sp.p:
It was my cauſe that you were ſo poſſeſt, and all
theſe troubles have from my peeviſh will origi ••• : I d •• ep • nt, though you forgive me n • t.

sp.speaker: Leſſ.
sp.p: You have no need for your repentance then which is due to it: all's now as at firſt it was wiſnt to be.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Why, that's well ſaid of all ſides. But ſoft, this Muſick has ſome other meaning: Another Wedding towards, Good ſpeed, good ſpeed.
sp.stage: Enter Compaſs and the four Gallants, Bride between Franckford •• d another, Luce, Nurſe, and Childe.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: We thank you, ſir.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Stay, ſtay, our neighbor Compaſs, is't not?

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: That was, and may be agen to morrow, this day Maſter Bridegroom.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Oh! give you joy. But ſir, if I be not miſtaken, you were married before now; how long is't ſince your wife died?

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Ever ſince yeſterday, ſir.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Why, ſhe's ſcarce buried yet then.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: No indeed, I mean to dig her grave ſoon, I had no leiſure yet.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: And was not your fair Bride married before?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Yes indeed, ſir.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: And how long ſince your huſband departed?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Juſt when my husbands wife died.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Bleſs us Hymen, are not theſe both the ſame parties?

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: Moſt certain, ſir.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: What Marriage call you this?

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: This is called Shedding of Horns, ſir.

sp.speaker: VVood.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Leſſ.
sp.p: Like enough, but they may grow agen next year.

sp.speaker: VVood.
sp.p: This is a new trick.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Yes ſir, becauſe we did not like the old trick.

sp.speaker: VVood.
sp.p: Brother, you are a helper in this deſign too.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: The Father to give the Bride, ſir.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: And I am his ſon, ſir, and all the ſons he has; and this is his Grand-childe, and my elder brother, you'l think this ſtrange now.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Then it ſeems he begat this before you?

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Before me? not ſo ſir, I was far enough off when 'twas done; yet let me ſee him dares ſay, this is not my Childe; and this my father.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: You cannot ſee him here, I think ſir.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Twice married! Can it hold?

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Hold? It ſhould hold the better, a wiſe man would think, when 'tis ty'd of two knots.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Methinks it ſhould rather unlooſe the firſt,
And between 'em both make up one Negative.

sp.speaker: Euſt.
sp.p: No ſir, for though it hold on the contrary, yet two Affirmatives make no Negative.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Cry you mercy, ſir.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Make what you will, this little Negative was my wifes laying, and I Affirm it to be mine own.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: This proves the marriage before ſubſtantial, having this iſſue

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: 'Tis mended now ſir; for being double married, I may now have two children at a birth, if I can get 'em. D'ye think Ile be five years about one, as I was before?

sp.speaker: Euſt.
sp.p: The like has bin done for the loſs of the Wedding-ring, And to ſettle a new peace before disjoynted.

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.p: But this indeed ſir, was eſpecially done, to avoid the word of Scandal, that foul word which the fatal Monologiſt cannot al • er.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: What's that, the Nighting • le?

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: A Night-bird, much good may do you, ſir.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Ile thank you when I'm at Supper. Come Father, Childe, and Bride; and for your part Father, whatſoever he, or he, or t'other ſays, you ſhall be as welcome as in my t'other wifes days.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: I thank you, ſir.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Nay, take us with you, Gentlemen:
One Wedding we have yet to ſolemnize,
The firſt is ſtill imperfect. Such troubles
Have drown'd our Muſick: but now I hope all's friends.
Get you to Bed, and there the Wedding ends.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: And ſo good night, my Bride and Ile to bed:
He that has Horns, thus let him learn to ſhed.

div.p: If any Gentlemen pleaſe to repair to my Houſe aforeſaid, they may be furniſhed with all manner of Engliſh, or French Hiſtories, Romances, or Poetry; which are to be ſold, or read for reaſonable Conſiderations.
